reasonable distance from any building, structure, or vehicle and from any
container or other source of flammable liquids or vapors. A metal fire ring or
commercially manufactured portable fireplace shall not be placed on any
combustible surface.
         b.   Fuel: The fuel shall be dry, seasoned wood or equal and no
household or landscape wastes or leaves shall be burned.
         c.   Attendance: No burning shall take place on private property
without the presence and oversight of an adult over eighteen (18) years of age.
No fires shall be left unattended until entirely extinguished.
   D.   Fires started and attended by village of Manhattan personnel or village
authorized contractors to burn materials collected within the corporate limits
of the village shall be authorized on any village owned property.
   E.   The provisions of this chapter shall not be exercised so as to impose
regulations or require permits with respect to land used or to be used for
agricultural purposes. In the event that the land ceases to be used solely for
agricultural purposes, then and only then shall the provisions of this chapter
apply.
   F.   Controlled burning of native grasses, upon receipt of permit from the
police chief or his designee and has been approved by the state or local
governmental agency having jurisdiction.
Any violation of the provisions of this section shall be considered a nuisance
and shall be subject to the penalty set forth in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 1033, 9-15-2009)
7-5-3: ACCUMULATION OF MATERIALS SUBJECT TO DECAY:
Excepting for compost piles, which shall remain subject to the nuisance
provisions of the village of Manhattan's codified ordinances, no person shall
permit or allow or cause to accumulate anywhere in the village any garbage or
refuse or other material subject to decay, other than leaves or grass. Compost
piles shall be placed in aesthetically acceptable compost structures and shall
be subject to the following regulations:
   A.   Definitions:
   COMPOST STRUCTURE(S): A structure or structures designed to hold composting
materials in such a way as to prevent material from being windblown and to
promote the composting process.
   COMPOSTING: Biological process by which microorganisms decompose the organic
fraction of waste, producing a humus like material that may be used as a soil
conditioner.
   B.   Regulations: It shall be unlawful to allow a compost structure to be
maintained on any part of any premises and parkway immediately adjacent to any
premises in violation of the following standards:
      1.   The minimum size for a compost structure shall be two feet (2') wide
by two feet (2') high by two feet (2') long. The maximum size of a compost
structure on a property shall not exceed a maximum of five feet (5') wide by
five feet (5') high by five feet (5') long.
      2.   Only the following organic materials shall be allowed in any such
compost structure:
         a.   Soil.
         b.   Landscape waste in which any woody materials and garden wastes
have been reduced in size to one-half (1/2) an inch in diameter and twelve
inches (12") long.
         c.   Cooked and uncooked fruits and vegetables.
         d.   Livestock manure.
         e.   Residential cardboard rolls.
         f.   Coffee grounds and filters.
         g.   Dryer and vacuum cleaner lint.
         h.   Eggshells.
         i.   Grass clippings.
         j.   Hay and straw.
         k.   Houseplants.
         l.   Leaves.
         m.   Nutshells.
         n.   Sawdust.
         o.   Tea bags.
         p.   Yard trimmings.
Provided, however, that small amounts of wood ash or fertilizer may be added to
provide nutrients.
      3.   The following materials shall not be allowed in any such compost
structure, including, but not limited to:
         a.   Construction and demolition debris, except sawdust.
         b.   Metal items.
         c.   Preservative treated wood products.
         d.   Petroleum products (gasoline, motor oil, paints, or solvents).
         e.   Pesticides or herbicides (except that which is already conveyed
as part of the organic materials described above).
         f.   Fish or animal feces.
         g.   Fish or animal carcasses.
         h.   Cooked meat scraps.
         i.   Human feces.
         j.   Paper.
         k.   Plastic or cardboard items.
      4.   Compost structures shall be maintained by turning the compost
material to permit aeration so as to prevent unpleasant odors and prevent the
attraction or harboring of rodents and pests.
      5.   Compost structures shall not be located in any front or side yard;
shall be set back at least twenty feet (20') from principal residential
structures on adjoining lots.
      6.   Compost structures shall not be located on any drainage easement.
      7.   Only materials generated by the residence located on the subject lot
may be placed in the compost structure located on the lot.
      8.   Only one compost structure shall be permitted on a lot.
      9.   Compost structures shall be permitted only on lots in residential
districts. (Ord. 1033, 9-15-2009)
7-5-4: ACCUMULATION OF MATERIALS THAT CAN BE BLOWN AWAY:
No person shall cause or permit to accumulate any dust, ashes or similar
materials that can be blown away by the wind, unless such materials are stored
in a covered or secure container. (Ord. 1033, 9-15-2009)
7-5-5: DEPOSIT ONTO PUBLIC STREETS OR ALLEYS:
No person shall deposit or permit to fall from any vehicle, or escape from any
property, any garbage, refuse or ashes onto any public street or alley in the
village. This subsection shall not be construed to prohibit the placing of
garbage, refuse or ashes in a container complying with the provisions of this
chapter in preparation to having such material collected and disposed of in a
manner provided for herein as long as no garbage, recycling material or
containers leave the property or parkway of the property generating the
garbage, refuse or ashes. (Ord. 1033, 9-15-2009)
7-5-6: DUMPING ON PRIVATE PROPERTY:
No person shall dump or place any garbage, refuse or ashes on any premises in
the village without the consent of the owner of such premises. (Ord. 1033, 9-
15-2009)
7-5-7: STORING OR DEPOSITING OF COMBUSTIBLE MATERIAL:
No person shall permit or store any combustible refuse in such a manner as may
create a hazard of fire, nor store or deposit any garbage, refuse or ashes of
any nature or kind whatever upon any alley, street or other public place within
the village, except as herein provided. (Ord. 1033, 9-15-2009)
7-5-8: DECLARATION OF NUISANCE:
No person shall deposit anywhere in the village any uncovered pile or
collection of refuse, garbage or ashes. Any uncovered piles of such refuse,
garbage or ashes are hereby declared to be a nuisance. (Ord. 1033, 9-15-2009)
7-5-9: CONTAINERS FOR COLLECTION:
No person shall dispose of any garbage, refuse or ashes anywhere in the village
except as herein provided. Such material shall be placed in covered or secure
containers, as herein provided, for collection by a licensed garbage and refuse
collector. No container shall be placed so as to constitute a nuisance to
adjacent property or to the occupants thereof. (Ord. 1033, 9-15-2009)
7-5-10: LEAF AND YARD WASTE COLLECTION:
A property owner, his or her tenant, agent(s) of the owner or tenant,
contractor(s), or landscaper(s) may place leaves and yard waste in a closed
biodegradable bag or maximum thirty (30) gallon cans labeled "Yard Waste Only"
curbside along public streets and on the public parkway for pick up by the
village licensed garbage collector at any time from the first Monday of April
to the second Monday of December. Closed biodegradable leaf bags or cans shall
not be placed less than ten feet (10') from any storm drain inlet, nor shall
they create a safety hazard for vehicles, bicyclists or pedestrians.
(Ord. 1033, 9-15-2009; amd. Ord. 1466-24, 7-2-2024)
CHAPTER 6
MANDATORY RECYCLING PROGRAM
SECTION:
7-6-1: Definition
7-6-2: Recycling Program
7-6-3: Recycling Containers
7-6-4: Separation Of Recyclables And Placement For Recyclables Removal
7-6-5: Mandatory Recycling
7-6-6: Collection By Unauthorized Persons
7-6-7: Penalty
7-6-1: DEFINITION:
   RECYCLABLES: Materials having an economic value in the secondary materials
market, acceptable for collection by the village's recycling contractor, which
currently include newsprint, cardboard, paper products, bottle glass (all
colors), aluminum cans, HDPE plastic (i.e., no. 1 and 2), PET plastic (2 liter
pop bottles), tin cans, aluminum trays (i.e., TV dinner type trays). (Ord. 581,
4-6-1993)
7-6-2: RECYCLING PROGRAM:
There is hereby established a recycling program for the mandatory separating of
recyclables from garbage and rubbish for residents in the village. (Ord. 581,
4-6-1993)
7-6-3: RECYCLING CONTAINERS:
All residents shall use recycling containers which will be issued by the
village and owned by the village. The initial distribution of recycling
containers to the village residents shall be of no cost to each resident due to
the fact that the village obtained a recycling grant to purchase the recycling
containers. Thereafter, replacement containers will be available for rental by
village residents from the village. The rental amounts will be fixed from time
to time by the village board and will be billed on the combined water and sewer
bill. No container other than those initially issued by the village or rented
from the village may be used for recycling. In the event a village resident
ceases to be a village resident, he will return the recycling containers to the
village. Upon the failure to do so, the cost of the container will be assessed
to the final combined water and sewer bill, or assessed as a lien on the
property. (Ord. 581, 4-6-1993)
7-6-4: SEPARATION OF RECYCLABLES AND PLACEMENT FOR RECYCLABLES REMOVAL:
All products the village designates as recyclable shall be prepared and
separated from all other refuse by residents and placed in village approved and
issued containers, as required, and shall be collected by the village's
curbside recycling contractor. Recyclables shall be placed in recycling
containers at curbside to be collected at times designated by the village.
(Ord. 581, 4-6-1993)
7-6-5: MANDATORY RECYCLING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to place for collection, removal or
disposal, any residential, household or solid waste, refuse or garbage which
also contains recyclable materials. (Ord. 581, 4-6-1993)
7-6-6: COLLECTION BY UNAUTHORIZED PERSONS:
From time of placement of acceptable recyclables at the curb for collection in
accordance with the terms hereof, said acceptable "recyclables", as defined
herein, shall be and become the property of the village's curbside recycling
contractor. It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person unauthorized
by the village to collect or pick up or cause to be collected recycling
containers in violation hereof from one or more locations. Each act described
in this section shall constitute a separate and distinct offense punishable as
hereinafter provided. (Ord. 581, 4-6-1993)
7-6-7: PENALTY:
Any person(s) who violates this chapter is subject to the penalties set out in
this section: (Ord. 581, 4-6-1993)
   A.   Any person convicted of a violation of any section or provision of this
chapter shall be punished by a fine as established in section
1-4-1 of this code for any one offense. (Ord. 791, 8-5-2003; amd. Ord. 1061, 4-
20-2010)
   B.   The penalties prescribed in this section are in addition to, and not in
lieu of, any other rights, remedies and penalties which the village may
otherwise seek to impose and may be available at law or in equity. (Ord. 581,
4-6-1993)
TITLE 8
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1
STREETS AND SIDEWALKS
SECTION:
8-1-1: Supervision Over Streets
8-1-2: Streets and Alleys
8-1-3: Sidewalks
8-1-4: Driveways Across Sidewalks
8-1-5: Injury to Streets, Sidewalks
8-1-6: Obstructing Streets, Sidewalks
8-1-7: Private Use
8-1-8: Encroachments
8-1-9: Barricades
8-1-10: Overhanging Signs
8-1-11: Depositing of Snow and Slush Upon Public Streets and Sidewalks
Prohibited
8-1-12: Penalty
8-1-1: SUPERVISION OVER STREETS:
The Superintendent of Public Works shall have control and supervision over all
the streets, sidewalks and other public places in the Village unless otherwise
provided by ordinance of the Village, and he shall superintend all paving and
repair work unless otherwise provided. He shall remove all obstructions, and
shall report to the Village Board any encroachments of any building or
structure onto the street line. (1928 Code §91)
8-1-2: STREETS AND ALLEYS:
   A.   Construction: No new pavement shall be laid, nor shall any repairs to
pavements in the streets or alleys be made by anyone other than the
Superintendent of Public Works without a permit from the Board of Trustees. All
new pavements and repairs shall be made in accordance with the specifications
laid down by ordinance. (1928 Code §92)
   B.   Drains: It shall be unlawful for anyone to injure or obstruct any drain
in or on any street, alley or other public place. (1928 Code §93)
   C.   Excavations: No person shall make any excavation in any street, alley
or other public place without having first obtained a permit therefor from the
Village Clerk. Excavations shall be refilled and the pavement restored as
promptly as possible. Every person making any excavation in any such place
shall give a bond, with sureties to be approved by the Clerk or the President,
to insure the prompt re-laying of the pavement, in the sum of one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00). (1928 Code §93; amd. 1990 Code)
   D.   Surface Drains: It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct or
deposit material in any surface drain along any street in the Village.
Any person desiring to construct a driveway across any such drain shall first
secure a permit therefor from the Board of Trustees; and all work on the
driveway must be done subject to the directions of the Board, and in the manner
prescribed by the Board. (1928 Code §95)
8-1-3: SIDEWALKS:
   A.   Construction: All sidewalks in the Village shall be built and
maintained by order of the President and Board of Trustees, in such manner and
of such width and material as may be directed by them. All walks, bridges and
culverts in any public place shall be laid and constructed under the
supervision of the Superintendent of Public Works, subject to supervision by
the Committee on Streets of the Board of Trustees. (1928 Code §96)
   B.   Specifications: No sidewalk in any public place shall be constructed of
materials other than cement or brick. The specifications for the construction
of the walk, and the amount to be allowed any owner who furnished labor or
material shall be determined by Village ordinance at the time of providing for
such sidewalk. (1928 Code §97)
   C.   Ownership: All sidewalks on a public street shall belong to the
Village, and all repair work thereon shall be done by the Village. (1928 Code
§98)
   D.   Accessibility to Handicapped: All new sidewalks shall be accessible to
the handicapped. (1990 Code)
8-1-4: DRIVEWAYS ACROSS SIDEWALKS:
It shall be unlawful to construct any driveway across any public sidewalk in
the village without having first obtained a permit therefor. Applications for
such permits shall be made in writing to the clerk and shall state thereon the
location of the proposed driveway and the purpose thereof.
All such driveways shall be constructed under the supervision of the
superintendent of public works, and he shall see to the enforcement of this
section.
No such driveway shall be constructed of any material other than cement; the
grade shall be as close to that of the adjacent sidewalk as is practicable, and
the driveway shall be so constructed that it will not interfere with the
pedestrians on the walk in any way. (1928 Code §99; amd. 1990 Code)
8-1-5: INJURY TO STREETS, SIDEWALKS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or in any manner do any injury to
any sidewalk, street, alley or other public place in the village. (1928 Code
§106)
8-1-6: OBSTRUCTING STREETS, SIDEWALKS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct in any way any street, alley or
sidewalk. The superintendent of public works is authorized to remove any
obstructions in any such place. (1928 Code §107)
8-1-7: PRIVATE USE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to use any street, sidewalk or other public
place as a place for the display or sale of goods or merchandise of any kind.
(1928 Code §108)
8-1-8: ENCROACHMENTS:
It shall be unlawful to erect or maintain any building or structure which
encroaches on any public street or property. (1928 Code §109)
8-1-9: BARRICADES:
Any person laying or repairing any pavement on any street, sidewalk or other
public place, or making an excavation in any such place shall maintain suitable
barricades to prevent injury to any person by reason of the work, and shall
have the barricades lighted at night. (1928 Code §110)
8-1-10: OVERHANGING SIGNS:
No person shall erect or maintain any sign or signboard extending over any
street, alley, sidewalk or other public place without having first obtained a
permit therefor. Permits for such signs shall be issued by the clerk and shall
state the location of the proposed sign.
All signs extending over any sidewalk, street, alley or other public place must
be securely fastened and constructed so that there will be no danger of the
same being dislodged by ordinary winds or falling from any other cause.
The lowest part of any sign or its support which extends over any public way
shall be at least eight feet (8') above the level of the walk or public way
over which it extends; but no sign shall be maintained over any public way used
by vehicles if any part of its support or of the sign is less than fifteen feet
(15') above the level of such public way. (1928 Code §111)
8-1-11: DEPOSITING OF SNOW AND SLUSH UPON PUBLIC STREETS AND SIDEWALKS
PROHIBITED:
No snow or slush removed from private property by way of shoveling, plowing or
blowing shall be deposited upon any village sidewalk or the paved section of
any public road, street or highway within the village. (Ord. 611, 1-17-1995)
8-1-12: PENALTY:
Any person convicted of a violation of any section or provision of this chapter
shall be punished by a fine as established in section
1-4-1 of this code for any one offense. Each day such violation is committed or
permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be
punishable as such hereunder. (Ord. 791, 8-5-2003; amd. Ord. 1061, 4-20-2010)
CHAPTER 2
TREES AND SHRUBBERY
SECTION:
8-2-1: Planting
8-2-2: Maintenance
8-2-3: Condition Of Life And Replacement Program
8-2-4: Injury To Trees, Shrubs
8-2-5: Dangerous Trees
8-2-6: Removal
8-2-7: Interference With Lights
8-2-8: Penalty
8-2-1: PLANTING:
It shall be unlawful to plant any trees or shrubs in any parkway outside of the
sidewalk line on any street or public way in the village.
(Ord. 1465-24, 7-2-2024)
8-2-2: MAINTENANCE:
Parkways are the property of the village however, if a new tree is planted,
there is a tree watering bag placed around the tree's trunk for about one (1)
month that public works will fill. Once the water bag is removed, it is the
homeowner's responsibility to continue to water the tree. Proper maintenance of
parkway trees should include but are not limited to watering the tree every ten
(10) days from the months of May - September to ensure proper growth.
(Ord. 1465-24, 7-2-2024)
8-2-3: CONDITION OF LIFE AND REPLACEMENT PROGRAM:
We want to hear from you regarding any unhealthy parkway trees in front of your
homes. Please call public works at (815) 418-2083 to request a service request
be filled out for your tree. A member of the public works department will come
and evaluate your parkway tree for the condition of the tree. We look to see if
it is still budding, declining, dead or hazardous. We will determine if we need
to place your tree on our removal/replacement list or if it will be added to
our watch list. Because of the high volume of calls we have been receiving for
parkway trees, we ask our residents to be patient with the removal and
replacement process. At this time we are taking service requests for parkway
tree inspections and have no set time schedule for removal and/or replacements.
For those residents that prefer not to wait for a parkway tree, you can bypass
the scheduled process and plant one on your own, at your cost or take advantage
of the village's parkway tree replacement program. If the tree is approved by
the superintendent of public works for the parkway tree replacement program,
the village will reimburse homeowners up to one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00)
for the purchase of two (2) parkway trees or three hundred dollars ($300.00)
for homeowners on a corner lot (up to 4 trees in the parkway). **Reimbursement
is only for the purchase of the tree not the removal or installation.
(Ord. 1465-24, 7-2-2024)
8-2-4: INJURY TO TREES, SHRUBS:
It shall be unlawful to injure any tree or shrub planted in any such parkway.
(1928 Code §101; amd. Ord. 1465-24, 7-2-2024)
8-2-5: DANGEROUS TREES:
Any tree or shrub which overhangs any public sidewalk or street in such a way
as to impede traffic or travel on such sidewalk or street shall be trimmed by
the owner of the abutting premises so that the obstruction shall cease. Any
tree or limb of a tree which shall become likely to fall on or across any
public walk or way shall be moved by the owner of the abutting premises. The
superintendent of public works and public works department is hereby authorized
to trim any such tree or shrub in any parkway, or to remove any shrub or tree
which obstructs traffic or travel or which endangers persons traveling on such
parkway.
(1928 Code §102; amd. Ord. 1465-24, 7-2-2024)
8-2-6: REMOVAL:
It shall be unlawful to remove or cut down any such tree without having
permission from the village prior to.
(Ord. 1465-24, 7-2-2024)
8-2-7: INTERFERENCE WITH LIGHTS:
All trees and shrubs in such parkways shall be kept trimmed by the owner of
abutting premises so that they shall not interfere with streetlights or wires
strung over the streets.
(1928 Code §104; amd. Ord. 1465-24, 7-2-2024)
8-2-8: PENALTY:
Any person convicted of a violation of any section or provision of this chapter
shall be punished by a fine as established in section
1-4-1 of this code for any one offense.
(Ord. 791, 8-5-2003; amd. Ord. 1061, 4-20-2010; Ord. 1465-24, 7-2-2024)
CHAPTER 3
RAILROADS
SECTION:
8-3-1: Crossing Lights
8-3-2: Sewers And Drains
8-3-3: Penalty
8-3-1: CROSSING LIGHTS:
It shall be the duty of every person owning or operating any railroad or tracks
through the corporate limits of the village to properly illuminate, with an
adequate lighting system, every place along such tracks or right of way where
any street or highway of the village crosses such tracks or right of way within
the village limits. Such lights shall be placed not less than fifteen feet
(15') above the grade center of such streets or highways at the crossing, and
all such lights shall be kept burning every night from dusk until dawn. (1928
Code §263; amd. 1990 Code)
8-3-2: SEWERS AND DRAINS:
It shall be the duty of every person owning or operating any railroad or tracks
through the corporate limits of the village to properly construct, maintain and
keep open sufficient drains, sewers, culverts and waterways along and under
such right of way to prevent the accumulation of water or filthy or stagnant
pools, and to permit the natural drainage of adjacent property to continue
unimpeded. (1928 Code §266)
8-3-3: PENALTY:
Any person convicted of a violation of any section or provision of this chapter
shall be punished by a fine as established in section
1-4-1 of this code for any one offense. Each day such violation is committed or
permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be
punishable as such hereunder. (Ord. 791, 8-5-2003; amd. Ord. 1061, 4-20-2010)
CHAPTER 4
WATER AND SEWER REGULATIONS

8-4A-2-9: Penalties
8-4A-1: CONNECTION TO SYSTEM:
   A.   Permit Required: No connection shall be made to the water or sewer
system of the Village, without the signed permit from the Village. Any
connection or opening made to the Village's water or sewer system, without a
signed permit from the Village, or in any manner different from the mode
prescribed for such opening or connection shall subject the maker to a penalty
as hereinafter provided.
   B.   Application For Permit: No person shall make any connection to the
water or sewer system of the Village, except upon written application to the
Village and the issuance of a permit by the Village for such connection. Each
application shall state the name of the applicant, the permit desired, the
location to be used and the fee to be paid. Each application shall also contain
such additional information as may be required by the Village.
   C.   Connection Fees: Any person, prior to making any connection to the
water or sewer system of the Village, shall, upon proper application to the
Village, pay to the Village a connection fee for each such connection. Any
person having previously paid a connection fee, but not having applied for
connection shall pay the difference between the amount paid and the amount
currently due for said connection at the time of application. Payment shall be
due and payable for connection in the amounts and time as set forth in the
following schedules:
      1.   Single family residential units shall pay the following amounts at
time of occupancy permit:

   E.   Penalty: Any person violating any provisions of this section shall be

8-4A-2: USER RATES AND CHARGES:
8-4A-2-1: BASIS FOR SERVICE CHARGES:
The wastewater service charge for the use of and for service supplied by the
water and sewer facilities of the Village shall consist of a basic user charge
for operation and maintenance plus replacement, a debt service charge and a
surcharge, if applicable. (Ord. 496, 9-20-1983)
   A.   Capital Improvement Charge: The capital improvement charge shall be
computed by determining the major maintenance and/or improvements to the
existing water and sewer systems, including, without limitation: repair or
replacement of water main, repair or replacement of sewer pipe, radium removal,
water storage maintenance, lift station maintenance, water well maintenance,
sewer plant maintenance and upgrades, and water meter replacement program.
(Ord. 891, 2-21-2006)
      1.   Temporary Infrastructure Fee: The temporary debt fee shall be
computed by determining the amount of major maintenance and/or improvements to
the water and sewer systems, including, without limitation: construction,
repair, and/or replacement of water main, sewer pipe, radium removal treatment
facility, water storage, lift station, water well, sewer plant, and water meter
replacement program. (Ord. 1060, 4-20-2010, eff. 5-1-2010)
   B.   Basic User Charge:
      1.   The basic user charge shall be based on water usage as recorded by
water meters and/or sewage meters for wastes having the following normal
concentrations:
         a.   A five (5) day, twenty degree centigrade (20°C) biochemical
oxygen demand (BOD) of two hundred milligrams per liter (200 mg/L).
         b.   A suspended solids (SS) content of two hundred fifty milligrams
per liter (250 mg/L).
      2.   It shall consist of operation and maintenance costs plus
replacement, along with the current rate for water service, and shall be
computed as follows:
         a.   Estimate the projected annual revenue required to operate and
maintain the wastewater facilities, including a Replacement Fund for the year,
for all works categories.
         b.   Proportion the estimated costs to wastewater facility categories
by volume, suspended solids and BOD, if possible.
         c.   Estimate wastewater volume, pounds of SS and pounds of BOD to be
treated.
         d.   Proportion the estimated costs to users by volume, suspended
solids and BOD.
         e.   Compute costs per one thousand (1,000) gallons for normal sewage
strength.
         f.   Compute surcharge costs per one thousand (1,000) gallons per
milligrams per liter in excess of normal sewage strength for BOD and SS.
         g.   Include the current rate for water service for users of the
Village's water system.
   C.   Surcharge: A surcharge will be levied to all users whose waters exceed
the normal concentrations for BOD (200 milligrams per liter) and SS (250
milligrams per liter). The surcharge will be based on water usage as recorded
by water meters and/or sewage meters for all wastes which exceed the two
hundred milligrams per liter (200 mg/L) and two hundred fifty milligrams per
liter (250 mg/L) concentration for BOD and SS respectively. Subsection
8-4A-2-2C of this article specifies the procedure to compute a surcharge.
   D.   Measurement Of Flow: The volume of flow used for computing basic user
charges and surcharges for users of the water and sewer facilities shall be the
metered water consumption read to the lowest even increments of one hundred
(100) gallons. Users of the sewer facilities who are not users of the Village's
water system shall be charged on a basis of a computed average flat rate user
charge. (Ord. 496, 9-20-1983)
8-4A-2-2: RATES AND CHARGES ESTABLISHED:
   A.   Capital Improvement Charge: A capital improvement charge of nine
dollars ninety five cents ($9.95) monthly to each user of the water and sewer
facilities of the village. The capital improvement charge shall be used for
major maintenance or improvements to the existing water or sewer facilities.
The rates for the capital improvement charge billed monthly shall automatically
increase by the lesser of five percent (5%) or the percentage increase in the
Chicago metropolitan statistical area consumer price index for the preceding
calendar year plus 1.5 percent effective for bills issued on and after May 1 of
each year. In the event the Chicago metropolitan statistical area consumer
price index is negative, the annual increase shall be 1.5 percent.
   B.   Basic User Rates:
      1.   Generally:
         a.   Metered Rates: There shall be and there is hereby established a
basic user rate for the use of and for service supplied by the combined water
and sewer facilities of the village as follows:
 
Water:                
   Per 1,000 gallo$4.55
Sewer:                
   Per 1,000 gallo4.05
 
         b.   Nonmetered Rates: All nonmetered residential users of the
wastewater facilities, and/or users of the wastewater facilities who are not
users of the village's water system shall be charged a minimum flat rate charge
based on the discharge of five thousand (5,000) gallons monthly at the sewer
only metered rate and the capital improvement charge as defined in subsection A
of this section.
The flat rate charge will allow a maximum of five thousand (5,000) gallons
monthly.
In the event use of the wastewater facilities is determined by the village to
be in excess of five thousand (5,000) gallons monthly, the village may require
such flat rate user to install metering devices on the water supply or sewer
main to measure the amount of water supplied.
         c.   Annual Increase: The rates for water and/or sewer service and
fees billed monthly shall automatically increase the lesser of five percent
(5%) or the percentage increase in the Chicago metropolitan statistical area
consumer price index for the preceding calendar year plus 1.5 percent effective
for bills issued on and after May 1 of each year for services rendered in the
preceding one month. In the event the Chicago metropolitan statistical area
consumer price index is negative, the annual increase shall be 1.5 percent.
         d.   Sewer Rate Cap: During the months of May, June, July, August, and
September, every user of the Village's sewer system shall be charged for the
first ten thousand (10,000) gallons discharged in each such month at the normal
rate, as set forth in this chapter. Any additional discharge in any such month
beyond the first ten thousand (10,000) gallons shall be billed at a rate of
zero dollars ($0.00).
      2.   Rates For Special Uses:
         a.   Water used in any construction work or for other temporary
purposes upon premises upon which no water meter is installed shall be paid for
by the contractor on said premises, and the contractor shall be required to
place a deposit with the water collector as estimated by the water department
for the full amount of the cost of such water as estimated by them before water
is supplied for such use.
         b.   For extraordinary uses and for purposes not hereinabove specified
and for other extraordinary or peculiar uses, rates and conditions for use of
water shall be subject to special permit and contract with the village board of
trustees. (Ord. 496, 9-20-1983)
         c.   Rates for bulk water sales will be a flat rate of fifty dollars
($50.00) plus two (2) times the current water rate per one thousand (1,000)
gallons. The water will be metered and supplied under the direct supervision of
the public works department. (Ord. 1178, 6-3-2014)
         d.   Effective July 31, 2007, separately metered lawn sprinkling
systems located on non one-family residential properties including apartment
buildings, commercial, industrial, governmental, and community open spaces;
shall be billed for water only service as defined in subsection B1a of this
section. (Ord. 968, 6-17-2007)
   C.   Surcharge Rate: The rates of surcharges for BOD5 and SS shall be as
follows:
      BOD5    = $0.2647 per pound
      SS   = 0.2250 per pound
The concentration of wastes used for computing surcharges shall be established
by waste sampling. Waste sampling shall be performed as often as may be deemed
necessary by the village and shall be binding as a basis for surcharges.
   D.   Computation Of Wastewater Service Charge: The wastewater service charge
shall be computed by the following formula:
      CW = CD + CM + (Vu - X)CU + CS
   Where CW    =   Amount of wastewater service charge ($) per billing period.
   CD   =   Debt service charge (subsection A of this section).
   CM   =   Minimum charge for operation, maintenance and replacement.
   Vu   =   Wastewater volume for the billing period.
   X   =   Allowable consumption in gallons for the minimum charge.
   CU   =   Basic user rate for operation, maintenance and replacement.
   CS   =   Amount of surcharge (subsection C of this section).
(Ord. 496, 9-20-1983; amd. Ord. 1172, 1-7-2014; Ord. 1386-22, 2-1-2022)
8-4A-2-3: BILLS FOR SERVICE; DELINQUENCIES:
   A.   Rendition Of Bills; Payment:
      1.   Bills: Rates or charges for service shall be payable monthly. The
owner of the premises, the occupant thereof and the user of the service shall
be jointly and severally liable to pay for service to such premises, and the
service is furnished to the premises by the village only upon the condition
that the owner of the premises, occupant and user of the services are jointly
and severally liable therefor.
Bills for service shall be sent out by the village by the tenth day of the
month succeeding the period for which the service is billed. All water and
sewer bills are due and payable on the last day of the month succeeding the
period for which the service is billed. A penalty of ten percent (10%) shall be
added to all bills not paid by the last day of the month succeeding the period
for which the service is billed.
   B.   Delinquencies:
      1.   Termination Of Service: If charges for sewer and/or water services
are not paid in full within fifteen (15) calendar days from the due date of the
billing and/or if the utility customer is in violation of any village
ordinance, regulation or law, the utility customer may be notified in writing
of the village's intent to terminate water or sewer service prior to any such
termination. In the event charges for water/sewer services are not paid within
fifteen (15) days after the due date of the bill for such services, such water/
sewer services shall be discontinued as hereinafter provided and shall not be
reinstated until such time as all violations are corrected and all outstanding
utility bills are paid in full in addition to the payment of a fifty dollar
($50.00) reinstatement fee.
      2.   Statement Of Lien: The village shall have a continuing lien upon the
premises and real estate upon or for which water is used or supplied for all
water rates or benefits accruing by reason of the provisions of this chapter.
Every such lien shall, upon compliance with the conditions set forth in this
chapter, become and be prior and superior to the rights and interest of
creditors, encumbrances, purchasers and other parties in interest in the
premises and real estate. Liens shall be filed following three (3) consecutive
months of nonpayment for water service charges to the village. A release of
lien shall be provided to the customer upon payment of all charges and fees;
such release may be recorded by the customer.
If the user whose bill is unpaid is not the owner of the premises and the
village clerk, or his/her designee, has notice of this, notice shall be mailed
to the owner of the premises, if his address be known to the clerk, whenever
such bill remains unpaid for fifteen (15) days after it has been due.
The failure of the village clerk to record such lien or to mail such notice or
the failure of the owner to receive such notice shall not affect the right to
foreclose the lien for unpaid bills as mentioned herein. (Ord. 891, 2-21-2006)
      3.   Foreclosure Of Lien: Property subject to a lien for unpaid charges
shall be sold for nonpayment of the same, and the proceeds of the sale shall be
applied to pay the charges, after deducting costs, as is the case in the
foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be by bill in equity in
the name of the village. The village attorney is hereby authorized and directed
to institute such proceedings in the name of the village in any court having
jurisdiction over such matters against any property for which the bill has
remained unpaid three hundred sixty five (365) days after it has been rendered.
(Ord. 496, 9-20-1983)
8-4A-2-4: CHANGES OF RATES AND CHARGES:
   A.   The rates for water service prescribed in this chapter may be changed
by the board of trustees at any time, and the village shall not be deemed to
have contracted with any consumer to maintain such rates for any period of time
whatsoever. Other charges prescribed by this chapter may be changed at any
time.
   B.   The adequacy of the wastewater service charge shall be reviewed
annually by certified public accountants for the village in their annual audit
report. The wastewater service charge shall be revised periodically to reflect
a change in debt service or a change in operation and maintenance costs
including replacement costs. (Ord. 496, 9-20-1983)
8-4A-2-5: LIABILITY FOR AND AVAILABILITY OF RATES AND CHARGES; APPEALS:
A copy of this article properly certified by the village treasurer, shall be
filed in the office of the recorder of deeds of Will County and shall be deemed
notice to all owners of real estate of the charges of the sewerage system of
the village on their properties.
The method for computation of rates and service charges established for user
charges under section
8-4A-2-2 of this article shall be made available to a user within five (5)
working days of receipt of a written request for such. Any disagreement over
the method used or in the computations thereof shall be remedied by the village
engineer within thirty (30) days after notification of a formal written appeal
outlining the discrepancies. (Ord. 496, 9-20-1983)
8-4A-2-6: DISPOSITION OF REVENUES:
All revenues and monies derived from the operation of the combined water and
sewer system shall be deposited in the water and sewerage account of the water
and sewerage fund. All such revenues and monies shall be held by the village
treasurer separate and apart from all other funds of the village, and all of
said sum, without any deductions whatever, shall be delivered to the village
treasurer not more than ten (10) days after receipt of the same, or at such
more frequent intervals as may from time to time be directed by the president
and board of trustees. The village treasurer shall receive all such revenues
from the sewerage system and all other funds and monies incident to the
operation of such system as the same may be delivered to him and deposit the
same in the account of the fund designated as the "water and sewerage fund of
the village of Manhattan". The treasurer shall administer such fund in every
respect in the manner provided by statute of the "revised cities and villages
act", effective January 1942. (Ord. 496, 9-20-1983)
8-4A-2-7: BOOKS AND ACCOUNTS:
   A.   The village treasurer shall establish a proper system of accounts and
shall keep proper books, records and accounts in which complete and correct
entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the combined water and
sewerage system, and at regular annual intervals, he shall cause to be made an
audit by an independent auditing concern of the books to show the receipts and
disbursements of the sewerage system.
In addition to the customary operating statements, the annual audit report
shall also reflect the revenues and operating expenses of the wastewater
facilities, including a replacement cost, to indicate that water and sewer
service charges under the waste cost recovery system do in fact meet these
regulations. In this regard, the financial information to be shown in the audit
report shall include the following:
      1.   Flow data showing total gallons received at the wastewater plant for
the current fiscal year.
      2.   Billing data to show total number of gallons billed.
      3.   Debt service for the next succeeding fiscal year.
      4.   Number of users connected to the system.
      5.   Number of nonmetered users.
   B.   The Illinois environmental protection agency or its authorized
representative shall have access to any books, documents, papers and records of
the village which are applicable to the village's system of user charges for
the purpose of making audit, examination, excerpts and transcriptions thereof
to ensure compliance with the terms of the special and general conditions to
any state grant. (Ord. 496, 9-20-1983)
8-4A-2-8: EFFECTIVE DATE OF RATES AND CHARGES:
(Rep. by Ord. 1060, 4-20-2010, eff. 5-1-2010)
8-4A-2-9: PENALTIES:
Any person convicted of a violation of any section or provision of this article
shall be punished by a fine as established in section
1-4-1 of this code. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to
continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such
hereunder. In addition to any other penalty authorized by this section, the
village may discontinue water service to any customer, building or premises for
violation of any provision of this article until the violation is cured. (Ord.
791, 8-5-2003; amd. Ord. 1061, 4-20-2010)
ARTICLE B. WATER USE AND SERVICE
SECTION:
8-4B-1: Water Service Connections
8-4B-2: Permit For Water Service
8-4B-3: Authority To Turn On Water
8-4B-4: Service Pipes
8-4B-5: Water Meters
8-4B-6: Plumbing Requirements
8-4B-7: Wasting Water
8-4B-8: Lawn Sprinkling Restrictions
8-4B-9: Prohibited Acts And Conditions
8-4B-10: Entry Powers; Obstructing Village Officials
8-4B-11: Rules And Regulations
8-4B-12: Penalty
8-4B-1: WATER SERVICE CONNECTIONS:
   A.   Permit Required; Supervision And Inspection: No connections with a
water main shall be made without a permit being issued and twenty four (24)
hours' notice having been given to the superintendent of public works or other
person designated by the president and board of trustees. All such connections
shall be made and all such work done at the expense of the applicant who shall
also furnish materials necessary for such work; all such connections shall be
made under the supervision of the superintendent and no connections shall be
covered until the work has been inspected by him. (Ord. 496, 9-20-1983)
   B.   Abandonment Of Wells Before Connection:
      1.   Abandonment Of Wells: No water from the village water supply shall
be turned on for service into any premises which is tapped on to the village
water mains, unless or until any and all existing water wells located on the
premises being served shall have been abandoned and properly sealed according
to the requirements propounded by the state and the Will County health
department. Such premises shall be subject to visual inspection by the village
to assure that the well has been sealed and properly abandoned.
      2.   Transfer Of Property And/Or Water Billing Accounts: Existing private
wells active on sites connected to the village water system shall be abandoned
and properly sealed according to the requirements propounded by the state and
the Will County health department at the time of transfer of property ownership
and/or transfer of water billing accounts. Such premises shall be subject to
visual inspection by the village to assure compliance with this subsection.
      3.   Construction Of New Wells Prohibited: No water well shall be
constructed, drilled, sunk or otherwise provided for in any manner or on any
parcel of land within the corporate limits of the village where connection to
the village water system is feasible as declared herein.
      4.   Nonresidential Structure: Every existing nonresidential structure,
place of business, public building or other premises to which the supply of
water would be necessary, convenient or desirable within the corporate limits
of the village to which the supply of public water is feasible as herein
declared, shall, within ninety (90) days after such water service becomes
feasible, tie into such public water supply and discontinue the use of any
private well. Such well to be abandoned and properly sealed according to the
requirements propounded by the state and the Will County health department.
Such premises shall be subject to visual inspection by the village to assure
compliance with this subsection.
      5.   Residential Structure: Every existing residential structure,
dwelling or other premises to which the supply of water would be necessary,
convenient or desirable within the corporate limits of the village to which the
supply of public water is feasible as herein declared, shall upon transfer of
property ownership, tie into such public water supply and discontinue the use
of any private well. Such well to be abandoned and properly sealed according to
the requirements propounded by the state and the Will County health department
at the time of transfer of property ownership. Such premises shall be subject
to visual inspection by the village to assure compliance with this subsection.
      6.   Definition: That connection to the village water system is hereby
found and declared to be "feasible" whenever any village water main, line,
pipe, gate or valve appropriate for connection to the system is located within
two hundred fifty feet (250') of any dwelling, residence, structure, place of
business, public building or other premises to which the supply of water would
be necessary, convenient or desirable.
      7.   Water Usage: It shall be unlawful to use water from any well
drilled, dug or installed in violation of this subsection. (Ord. 603, 9-6-1994)
      8.   Penalty: Any person violating or failing to comply with any of the
terms or provisions of this subsection shall be guilty of a petty offense and,
on conviction thereof, shall be subject to a fine as established in section
1-4-1 of this code, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each
and every day on which a violation continues or is permitted to exist. (Ord.
603, 9-6-1994; amd. Ord. 1061, 4-20-2010)
8-4B-2: PERMIT FOR WATER SERVICE:
   A.   Permit Required; Restriction On Issuance: No person shall take any
water from any main hydrant or other part or portion of the village waterworks
system except upon application to the village and the issuance by the village
of a permit in accordance with the provisions of this ordinance, and no permit
shall be issued unless said water shall be measured through a meter in
accordance with the provisions of this ordinance.
   B.   Application For Permit; Fee: Application to have the water turned on
shall be made in writing to the village clerk and shall contain an agreement by
the applicant to abide by and accept all of the provisions of this ordinance as
conditions governing the use of the village water supply by the applicant. A
fee of thirty five dollars ($35.00) shall be paid for turning on the water.
(Ord. 538, 11-21-1989)
8-4B-3: AUTHORITY TO TURN ON WATER:
No water from the village water supply shall be turned on for service into any
premises by any person but the superintendent of public works or some person
authorized by him to perform this service. (Ord. 538, 11-21-1989)
8-4B-4: SERVICE PIPES:
   A.   Installation: All service pipes from the mains to the premises served
shall be installed by and at the cost of the owner of the property to be served
or the applicant for the service. Such installation shall be under the
inspection of the building inspector or such other person as designated by the
president of the board of trustees.
   B.   Pipe Specifications: No service shall be installed unless it conforms
to specifications drawn up by the board of trustees and approved thereby, a
copy of which specifications shall be kept on file by the clerk and shall be
open to inspection by any person interested.
   C.   Repairs: All repairs for service pipes and plumbing systems of
buildings shall be made by and at the expense of the owners of the premises
served. The village may, in case of an emergency, repair any service pipe, and
if this is done, the cost of such repair work shall be repaid to the village by
the owner of the premises served.
   D.   Excavations: Excavations for installing service pipes or repairing the
same shall be made in compliance with the village ordinance provisions relating
to making excavations in streets 1 ; provided, that it shall be unlawful to
place any service pipe in the same excavation with, or directly over, any drain
pipe or sewer pipe.
   E.   Shutoff Boxes: Shutoff boxes or service boxes shall be placed on every
service pipe and shall be located between the curb line and the sidewalk line,
where this is practicable. Such boxes shall be so located that they are easily
accessible and shall be protected from frost.
   F.   Installation Of Stop: A separate stop shall be placed on the service
pipe just inside the building wall on the influent side of the water meter.
Such stop shall be equal in quality to the service cock. (Ord. 496, 9-20-1983)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection
  8-1-2C of this title for excavations in streets and alleys.
8-4B-5: WATER METERS:
All premises using the Village water supply must be equipped with a water meter
furnished and owned by the Village.
   A.   Installation of Meters: Upon proper application to the Village and
payment of the water meter installation fee, as outlined in section
8-4B-5 (B) of this chapter, the Village shall furnish every consumer a water
meter and a Meter Transceiver Unit (MXU). The Village shall be solely
responsible for the installation of the water meter and the MXU.
      1.   A proper meter connection shall be provided upon each property
supplied with water in a readily accessible location and in a manner
satisfactory to the Superintendent of Public Works or his authorized
representative. Similarly, all such meters shall be so placed and unobstructed
so that it will not be necessary for the meter reader to move boxes, cabinets,
appliances, tables or other objects obscuring the meter.
      2.   The meter shall be installed in a horizontal plane with the dial
face up and as near to the shut-off valve where the service pipe enters the
building as is practicable. There shall not be any bypass or connection around
the meter.
      3.   The meter shall be installed inside of the building unless prior
authorization is received from the Water Department to install the meter in an
outside meter pit. Such pit shall be built at the owner's expense, shall
provide adequate protection against freezing and shall be built as directed by
the Superintendent of Public Works or his authorized representative and to his
entire satisfaction.
      4.   Each meter must be installed with an outside remote meter reader
unless prior authorization is received from the Water Department which waives
the installation of an outside remote meter reader. Where required, the meter
shall be located on the building a minimum of three feet (3') above the ground
and easily accessible and readable. It shall not be installed on a building in
a fenced-in area nor any other area blocked to the Village employee reading the
meter.
      5.   Whenever meters are placed on pipe connected by boilers or other hot
water apparatus, a check valve must be placed between said meter and such
boiler or other hot water apparatus to protect such meter from back pressure of
steam or hot water. (Ord. 496, 9-20-83)
   B.   Water Meter Installation Fee: There is a one-time installation fee for
the installation of each meter and Meter Transceiver Unit (MXU) by the Village
in accordance with the following table of meter sizes:
 
METER SIZES INSTALLATION FEE
5/8 x 3/4"  $345.00
3/4 x 3/4"  $355.00
1"          $414.00
1 1/2"      $710.00
2" R2       $890.00
2" C2       $1,540.00
 
The meter fee shall be payable prior to the installation of the water meter and
MXU unit.
   C.   Number of Meters Required: Each residence, dwelling, structure, mobile
home, school, business or commercial establishment which is supplied water by
the Village shall have a separate meter for each water service pipe entering
the premises.
   D.   Maintenance and Repair:
      1.   The Water Department reserves the right at any time to enter any
premises supplied by Village water and to exchange any meter, for repairs or
otherwise, as may be deemed necessary by the Department.
      2.   All meters installed shall be maintained and repaired by the Water
Department when rendered unserviceable through reasonable wear and tear;
provided, however, that where replacements, repairs or adjustments of any
meters are rendered necessary by any act, neglect or carelessness of the owner
or occupant of any premises or where meters are damaged by freezing, hot water,
etc., any expense caused the Water Department thereby shall be charged against
and be collected from the owner or occupant of the premises.
      3.   In case of breakage, stoppage or any other irregularity in the
meter, the owner or occupant is to notify the Water Department immediately, and
any necessary repairs will be made by the department, as hereinbefore provided.
(Ord. 496, 9-20-1983)
   E.   Testing Meters; Faulty Meters:
      1.   The accuracy of the meter on any premises will be tested by an
independent party selected by the water department upon written request of the
owner who shall pay in advance a fee of seventy five dollars ($75.00) to cover
the cost of the test. If, on such test, the meter shall be found to register
more than five percent (5%) more water than actually passes through it, another
meter will be substituted or proper repairs made and the fee of seventy five
dollars ($75.00) will be refunded to the owner.
No deduction shall be made for leakage after the water has passed through and
has been registered by the meter. (Ord. 1115, 8-21-2012)
      2.   If a meter fails at any time to register the quantity of the water
or becomes defective so that said meter does not give the true reading of the
quantity of water passing through the same, then such quantity of water shall
be reasonably estimated and the charge to be made to the customer shall be
based upon the average quantity registered through said meter during a
reasonably comparable period of time prior to the date of the failure of said
meter as the village shall direct. (Ord. 496, 9-20-1983; amd. Ord. 538, 11-21-
89; Ord. 1387-22, 2-1-2022)
8-4B-6: PLUMBING REQUIREMENTS:
No water shall be turned on for service in premises in which the plumbing does
not comply with the provisions of this chapter; provided, that water may be
turned on for construction work in unfinished buildings, subject to the
provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 496, 9-20-1983)
8-4B-7: WASTING WATER:
If it shall be found that there is an unreasonable or unnecessary waste of
water in any building, structure or premises to which water is supplied from
the waterworks system of the village through or by means of the leak located in
any such building or structure, or in or on any such premises, or if there is a
waste of water by any other means, then the village may cause the water supply
to be cut off from that building, structure or premises, unless such water leak
shall be stopped or repaired. Any other waste which is unreasonable and
unnecessary shall result in a cessation of water to the user by the village.
The village shall give to the owner, tenant or water user who is perpetrating
the water waste at least twenty four (24) hours' notice of the intention of the
village to shut off the water. The water supply shall not again be turned on
until the water leak or water waste has been corrected and until the village
has been paid the cost and expense of shutting off and again turning on the
water supply to said building, structure or premises by the owner, occupant or
person in possession. The cost for turning the water off and on shall be twelve
dollars ($12.00). (Ord. 496, 9-20-1983)
8-4B-8: LAWN SPRINKLING RESTRICTIONS:
Between the dates of May 15 and September 15, the sprinkling/watering of lawns
with water from the village public water supply is hereby limited to even
numbered sides of the street on even numbered calendar days and odd numbered
sides of the street on odd numbered calendar days during the hours of four
o’clock (4:00) A.M. to eleven o’clock (11:00) A.M. or seven o’clock (7:00) P.M.
to eleven o’clock (11:00) P.M. each day.
The use of any water from the village public water supply shall be further
limited or not permitted for nonhealth essential purposes when it has been
determined by the Village President that an adequate supply of water or water
pressure is not available for drinking and health related purposes, fire
protection and other emergency uses. Notice of such water use or restriction
shall be disseminated through reasonable communication media throughout the
Village, including, but not limited to, posted on a sign at each subdivision/
street entrance. (Ord. 969, 6-17-2007; amd. Ord. 1397-22, 6-7-2022; Ord. 1463-
24, 6-18-2024)
8-4B-9: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   Resale Of Water: No water shall be resold or distributed by the
recipient thereof from the village supply to any premises other than that for
which application has been made and the meter installed, except in case of
emergency.
   B.   Tampering With System: It shall be unlawful for any person not
authorized by the village to tamper with, alter or injure any part of the
village waterworks or supply system or break the seal of any meter or in any
way tamper with the same. A fee of twelve dollars ($12.00) shall be charged to
reseal a meter. (Ord. 496, 9-20-1983)
8-4B-10: ENTRY POWERS; OBSTRUCTING VILLAGE OFFICIALS:
No person shall in any manner obstruct or cause to be obstructed the free
access of any officer, agent or employee of the village to any stopcock, water
meter, shutoff box or connection with any water main or service pipe whenever
such officer, agent or employee shall desire access thereto. The officers of
the village and any and all persons delegated or authorized by the village for
such purpose shall have free access to all or any part of the building,
structure or premises into which any such officer or employee shall desire to
make entry or to have access for the purposes herein specified who shall refuse
to permit such entry or access or who shall do or cause to be done any act or
thing for the purpose of preventing such entry or access shall be deemed to be
guilty of a violation of this article and shall be punished as herein provided.
(Ord. 496, 9-20-1983)
8-4B-11: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The water committee of the board of trustees shall have the right to enact
reasonable rules and regulations concerning the operation, maintenance and use
of the waterworks system of the village, and the water department shall be
charged with the responsibility of enforcing said rules and regulations. Said
rules and regulations shall be in compliance with this article; provided,
however, that said rules and regulations must be on file in the village hall
and when they are changed, notice of such change must be published in a
newspaper having general circulation. (Ord. 496, 9-20-1983)
8-4B-12: PENALTY:
Any person convicted of a violation of any section or provision of this article
shall be punished by a fine as established in section
1-4-1 of this code for any one offense. (Ord. 791, 8-5-2003; amd. Ord. 1061, 4-
20-2010)
ARTICLE C. SEWER USE AND SERVICE
SECTION:
8-4C-1: Definitions

8-4C-6-2: Prohibited Discharges
8-4C-6-3: Materials Under Special Review

8-4C-6-5: Preliminary Treatment
8-4C-6-6: Industrial Users
8-4C-6-7: Measurements, Tests And Analyses
8-4C-6-8: Special Agreements

8-4C-8: Protection From Damage
8-4C-9: Powers And Authority Of Inspectors
8-4C-10: Violations And Penalties
8-4C-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meanings of terms used
in this ordinance shall be as follows:
   ADMINISTRATOR: The administrator of the United States environmental
protection agency.
   BOD (Denoting BIOCHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND): That amount of oxygen, expressed
in milligrams per liter, utilized in five (5) days at twenty degrees Celsius
(20°C) for biochemical oxidation of the organic material present in wastewater.
   BASIC USER CHARGE: The basic assessment levied on all users of the public
sewer system.
   BUILDING DRAIN: That part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage
system which receives the wastewater discharge from soil, waste and other
wastewater drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to
the building sewer, beginning five feet (5') outside the inner face of the
building wall.
   BUILDING SEWER: The extension from the building drain to the public sewer or
other place of disposal; also called house connection.
   CHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND (COD): The quantity of oxygen utilized in the
chemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedures.
   COMBINED SEWER: A sewer intended to receive both "wastewater", as defined
herein, and storm or surface water.
   COMBINED WATER AND SEWER CHARGE: The charge bimonthly levied on all users of
the combined water and sewer system. The service charge shall be computed as
outlined in section
8-4A-2 of this chapter and shall consist of the total or the basic user charge,
the debt service charge and a surcharge, if applicable.
   COMPATIBLE POLLUTANT: Biochemical oxygen demand, suspended solids, pH and
fecal coliform bacteria, plus additional pollutants identified in the NPDES
permit if the publicly owned treatment works was designed to treat such
pollutants and in fact does remove such pollutants to a substantial degree.
   CONSTRUCTION DRAINAGE: Water accumulated in excavations, water taken from
the ground through a well-point, underdrain or other dewatering system, water
accumulated as a result of grading and all other drainage associated with
construction operation.
   CONTROL MANHOLE: A structure located on a site from which industrial wastes
are discharged. Where feasible, the manhole shall have an interior drop. The
purpose of a "control manhole" is to provide access for the sanitary district
representative to sample and/or measure discharges.
   COOLING WATER: The unpolluted water from any system for condensing, air
conditioning, cooling, refrigeration or other use, and shall be free from odor
and oil.
   DEBT SERVICE CHARGE: The amount to be paid each billing period for payment
of interest, principal and coverage of outstanding loans, bonds, etc., and
shall be computed by dividing the annual debt service by the number of users
connected to the wastewater facilities.
   DIRECTOR: The Director of the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency.
   EASEMENT: An acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by
others.
   EFFLUENT CRITERIA: As defined in any applicable NPDES permit.
   FEDERAL GRANT: The United States government participation in the financing
of the construction of treatment works as provided for by the Title II - Grants
for Construction of Treatment Works of the Act and implementing regulations.
   FLOTABLE OIL: Oil, fat or grease in a physical state such that it will
separate by gravity from wastewater shall be considered free of flotable fat if
it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the
collection system.
   GARBAGE: The animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling,
preparation, cooking and serving of foods.
   INCOMPATIBLE POLLUTANT: Any pollutant not listed as a compatible pollutant.
   INDUSTRIAL USER: The definition of "industrial user", defined under section
35.905 of title 40 of the Federal Register and published in Volume 43, No. 183
of the Federal Register dated September 27, 1978, is hereby adopted and, in
addition thereto, shall include those users whose flow rates bear
characteristics which are abnormal from the standards set forth herein.
Any user may be excluded from this industrial user class if it is determined
that such user will introduce primarily segregated domestic wastes or wastes
from sanitary conveniences.
   INDUSTRIAL WASTES: Any solid, liquid or gaseous substance discharged,
permitted to flow or escaping from any industrial, manufacturing, commercial or
business establishment or process or from the development, recovery or
processing of any natural resource as distinct from sanitary sewage.
   INFILTRATION: The water, other than wastewater, that enters a sewerage
system (including sewer service connections) from the ground through such means
as, but not limited to, defective pipes, pipe joints, connections or manholes.
Infiltration does not include and is distinguished from inflow.
   INFILTRATION/INFLOW: The total quantity of water from both infiltration and
inflow without distinguishing the source.
   INFLOW: The water, other than wastewater, that enters a sewerage system
(including service connections) from sources such as, but not limited to, roof
leaders, cellar drains, yard and area drains, foundation drains, cooling
towers, drains from springs and swampy areas, manhole covers, cross-
connections between storm sewers and sanitary sewers, catch basins,
stormwaters, surface runoff, street wash waters or drainage. Inflow does not
include, and is distinguished from infiltration.
   INTERCEPTOR SEWER: A sewer whose primary purpose is to transport wastewater
from collector sewers to a treatment facility.
   MAJOR CONTRIBUTING INDUSTRY: An industrial user of the publicly-owned
treatment works that has: (A) a flow greater than 25.000 gpd per average
workday; or (B) has a flow greater than five percent (5%) of the flow carried
by the municipal system receiving its wastes; or (C) has in its waste, a toxic
pollutant in amount as defined in standards issued under section 307(a) of the
Act; or (D) Is found by the permit issuance authority, in connection with the
issuance of an NPDES permit to the publicly-owned treatment works receiving the
waste, to have significant impact, either singly or in combination with other
contributing industries, on that treatment works or upon the quality of
effluent from that treatment works.
   MAY: Is permissive (see also "Shall").
   MILLIGRAMS PER LITER: A unit of the concentration of water or wastewater
constituent. It is 0.001 g of the constituent in 1,000 ml of water. It has
replaced the unit formerly used commonly, parts per million, to which it is
approximately equivalent, in reporting the results of water and wastewater
analysis.
   MUNICIPALITY: The Village of Manhattan.
   NATURAL OUTLET: Any outlet, including storm sewers, in a watercourse, pond,
ditch, lake or other body or surface or ground water.
   NORMAL DOMESTIC SEWAGE: All household-type discharges from places of human
habitation including sanitary conveniences, kitchen and laundry wastes.
Discharge waste strength shall be considered to average 200 mg/l BOD and 250
mg/l suspended solids at a discharge rate of 100 gallons per capita per day.
This loading equates to .17 pounds of BOD and .20 pounds of suspended solids
per capita per day.
   NPDES PERMIT: The National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System permit
that is issued by the USEPA setting the limits on constituents that the
permittee may legally discharge. The limits are set in both concentration and
quantity.
   PERSON: Any individual, firm, company, association, society, corporation or
group.
   pH: The logarithm of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration. The
concentration is the molecular weight of hydrogen ions in grams per liter of
solution.
   POPULATION EQUIVALENT: A term used to evaluate the impact of industrial or
other waste on a treatment works or streams. One population equivalent is 100
gallons of sewage per day, containing 0.17 pounds of BOD and 0.20 pounds of
suspended solids.
ppm: Parts per million by weight.
   PRETREATMENT: The treatment of wastewaters from sources before introduction
into the wastewater treatment works.
   PROPERLY SHREDDED GARBAGE: The wastes from the preparation, cooking and
dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles
will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public
sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (1/2") in any dimension.
   PUBLIC SEWER: A sewer provided by or subject to the jurisdiction of the
Village. It shall also include sewers within or outside the Village boundaries
that serve one or more persons and ultimately discharge into the Village
sanitary sewer system, even though those sewers may not have been constructed
with Village funds.
   PUBLIC BUILDING: Is hereby determined to be a building to be used by the
public for religious, educational, charitable or governmental purposes.
Classification of said building to be made solely by the Board of Trustees.
   REPLACEMENT: Expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment,
accessories or appurtenances which are necessary during the service life of the
treatment works to maintain the capacity and performance for which such works
were designed and constructed. The term "operation and maintenance" includes
replacement.
   SANITARY SEWER: A sewer intended to carry only sanitary or sanitary and
industrial wastewaters from residences, commercial buildings industrial plants
and institutions.
   SEWAGE: The spent water of a community. The preferred term is "wastewater"
as defined herein.
   SEWAGE COLLECTION SYSTEM: All of the common lateral sewers within a
publicly-owned treatment system which are primarily installed to receive
wastewaters directly from facilities which convey wastewater from individual
structures or from private property and which includes service connection "Y"
fittings designed for connection with those facilities. The facilities which
convey wastewater from individual structures, from private property to the
public lateral sewer, or its equivalent, are specifically excluded from the
definition with the exception of pumping units and pressurized lines for
individual structures or groups of structures, when such units are cost-
effective and are owned and maintained by the District.
   SEWAGE FUND: The principal accounting designation for all revenues received
in the operation of the sewerage system.
   SEWER: A pipe or conduit that carries wastewater or drainage water.
   SEWERAGE: The system of sewers and appurtenances for the collection,
transportation and pumping of sewage.
   SHALL: Is mandatory (see also "May").
   SLUG: Any discharge of water or wastewater which in concentration of any
given constituent or in quantity of flow, exceeds, for any period of duration
longer than fifteen (15) minutes more than five (5) times the average twenty
four (24) hour concentration of flows during normal operation and shall
adversely affect the collection system and/or performance of the wastewater
treatment works.
   STANDARD METHODS: The examination and analytical procedures set forth in the
most recent edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and
Wastewater" published jointly by the American Public Health Association, the
American Water Works Association and the Water Pollution Control Federation.
   STATE ACT: The Illinois Anti-Pollution Bond Act of 1970.
   STATE GRANTS: The State of Illinois participation in the financing of the
construction of treatment works as provided for by the Illinois Anti-Pollution
Bond Act and for making such grants as filed with the Secretary of State of the
State of Illinois.
   STORM SEWER: A sewer intended to carry only storm waters, surface runoff,
street wash waters and drainage water, ground water, subsurface water or
unpolluted water from any source.
   STORM WATER RUNOFF: That portion of the precipitation that is drained into
the sewers.
   SURCHARGE: The assessment, in addition to the basic user charge and debt
service charge, which is levied on those persons whose waters are greater in
strength than the concentration values established in Section
8-4A-2 of this Chapter.
   SUSPENDED SOLIDS: Filterable solids, expressed in milligrams per liter,
contained in wastewater.
   THE ACT: The Clean Water Act (33 U.S.C. 1251 et seq., as amended).
   UNPOLLUTED WATER: Water of quality equal to or better than the effluent
criteria in effect, or water that would not cause violation of receiving water
quality standards and would not be benefited by discharging to the sanitary
sewers and wastewater treatment facilities provided.
   USEFUL LIFE: The estimated period during which the collection system and/or
treatment works will be operated and shall be twenty (20) years from the date
of startup of any wastewater facilities constructed with a State grant.
   USER CHARGE: A charge levied on users of treatment works for the cost of
operation and maintenance.
   USER TYPES:
Commercial User: Includes transit lodging, retail and wholesale establishments
or places engaged in selling merchandise or rendering service.
Industrial User: Any nongovernmental user of publicly owned treatment works
identified in the Standard Industrial Classification Manual, 1972, Office of
Management and Budget, as amended and supplemented, under the following
divisions:
   A.   Division A--Agriculture, Forestry Fishing.
   B.   Division B--Mining.
   C.   Division D--Manufacturing.
   D.   Division E--Transportation, Communications, Electric, Gas and Sanitary
Services.
   E.   Division I--Services.
Residential User: All dwelling units such as houses, mobile homes, apartments,
permanent multi-family dwellings.
User Class: The type of user either "residential", "commercial" (non-
industrial) or "industrial" as defined herein.
A user in the divisions listed may be excluded if it is determined by the
Village that it will introduce primarily segregated domestic wastes or wastes
from sanitary conveniences.
   VILLAGE: The Village of Manhattan, Will County, Illinois and the President
and Board of Trustees thereof.
   WASTEWATER: The spent water of a community. From the standpoint of source,
it may be a combination of the liquid- and water-carried wastes from
residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions, together
with any ground water, surface water and storm water that may be present.
   WASTEWATER FACILITIES: The structures, equipment and processes required to
collect, carry away, and treat domestic and industrial wastes and dispose of
the effluent.
   WASTEWATER TREATMENT WORKS: An arrangement of devices and structures for
treating wastewater, industrial wastes and sludge. Sometimes used as synonymous
with "waste treatment plant" or "wastewater treatment plant" or "water
pollution control plants" or "sewage treatment plant".
   WATER QUALITY STANDARDS: As defined in the Water Pollution Regulations of
Illinois.
   WATERCOURSE: A naturel or artificial channel for the passage of water either
continuously or intermittently. (Ord. 496, 9-20-83)
8-4C-2: USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS REQUIRED:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be
deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the
Village or in any area under the jurisdiction of the Village any human or other
objectionable waste.
   B.   It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the
Village or in any area under the jurisdiction of the Village any wastewater or
other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in
accordance with subsequent provisions of this Ordinance.
   C.   Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or
maintain any privy or privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility
intended or used for the disposal of wastewater.
   D.   The owner(s) of all houses, buildings or properties used for human
occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes situated within the
Village, and abutting on any street, alley or right of way in which there is
now located or may in the future be located a public sanitary sewer of the
Village, is hereby required, at the owner(s) expense, to install suitable
toilet facilities therein and to connect such facilities directly with the
proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this Ordinance within
ninety (90) days after date of official notice to do so; provided, that said
public sewer is within two hundred feet (200') of the property line as long as
the residence is within the Village. (Ord. 496, 9-20-83)
8-4C-3: PRIVATE WASTEWATER DISPOSAL SYSTEMS:
   A.   Private System Required: Where a public sanitary sewer is not available
under the provisions of subsection
 8-4C-2D of this Article, the building sewer shall be connected to a private
wastewater disposal system complying with the provisions of this Section.
   B.   Permit Requirements:
      1.   Permit Required; Application: Before commencement of construction of
a private wastewater disposal system within the limits of the Village, the
owner shall first obtain a written permit signed by the President of the
Village Board of Trustees. The application for such permit shall be made on the
form furnished by the Village and described as follows:
   APPLICATION FOR
   PRIVATE WASTEWATER DISPOSAL

   (Lot No. - Block - Subdivision)

wastewater disposal facility to serve the

building at said location.

described property.
   THE UNDERSIGNED AGREES: That this permit will be issued only if (a) the
above requirements are satisfied, (b) it is not possible to connect to a public
sanitary sewer, (c) the owner agrees to abandon the facility if a public sewer
becomes available, (d) the owner will abide by all Village Ordinances, (e) and
the facility will be operated and maintained in a sanitary manner at no expense
to the Village.
