10-1-9: Vehicle Load Weights; Exceptions; Permits
10-1-10: Engine Braking
10-1-11: Violations, Penalties
10-1-1: MOTOR VEHICLE CODE ADOPTED:
   A.   625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-100 to 5/20-204, as the same may be
amended from time to time, are hereby adopted and incorporated by reference as
the motor vehicle code traffic ordinance of the Village of Manhattan, Will
County, Illinois. All citations issued pursuant to this section that are to be
prosecuted in the Will County Circuit County by the village prosecutor shall be
written in the name of the village and shall refer to the corresponding
numbered sections of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-100 to 5/20-204, and
shall designate the violation as an ordinance violation on the traffic
citation, ticket, complaint, or compliance ticket. The village hereby declares
that the citations issued for the width of vehicles pursuant to section 15-102
of the Illinois vehicle code, the height of vehicles pursuant to section 15-103
of the Illinois vehicle code, and the length of vehicles pursuant to section
15-107 of the Illinois vehicle code may, at the police officer’s discretion, be
written so as to be administratively adjudicated pursuant to the village’s
administrative adjudication system pursuant to title 1, chapter 20 of this
code.
   B.   625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-401(d) and 5/3-815, as the same may
be amended from time to time, are hereby adopted and incorporated by reference
as the registration of second division vehicles ordinance of the Village of
Manhattan, Will County, Illinois. All citations issued pursuant to this section
shall be in the name of the village and shall refer to the corresponding
numbered sections of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-401(d) and 5/3-815 and
shall designate the violation as an ordinance violation on the traffic
citation, ticket, complaint, or compliance ticket.
   C.   625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-100 to 5/15-319, as the same may be
amended from time to time, are hereby adopted and incorporated by reference as
the size, weight, and load permits ordinance of the village of Manhattan, Will
County, Illinois. All citations issued pursuant to this section that are to be
prosecuted in the Will County Circuit Court by the village prosecutor shall be
in the name of the village and shall refer to the corresponding numbered
sections of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-100 to 5/15-319 and shall
designate the violation as an ordinance violation on the traffic citation,
ticket, complaint, or compliance ticket. The village hereby declares that the
citations issued for the width of vehicles pursuant to section 15-102 of the
Illinois vehicle code, the height of vehicles pursuant to section 15-103 of the
Illinois vehicle code, and the length of vehicles pursuant to section 15-107 of
the Illinois vehicle code may, at the police officer’s discretion, be written
so as to be administratively adjudicated pursuant to the villager’s
administrative adjudication system pursuant to title 1, chapter 20 of this
code.
   D.   Unless as otherwise provided, all fines and penalties for violations
shall be in accordance with the fines and penalties established in 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/1-100 to 5/20-204. (Ord. 1044, 1-19-2010) The minimum fine
shall be seventy-five dollars ($75.00) unless a higher fine is provided in the
Illinois Vehicle Code.
(Ord. 1044, 1-19-2010; amd. Ord. 1426-23, 4-18-2023; Ord. 1474-24, 9-17-2024)
10-1-2: UNLICENSED VEHICLES AND DRIVERS:
   A.   Unlicensed Vehicles: No person, whether he is licensed or unlicensed by
this state or any other state, shall drive any motor vehicle within the village
limits unless said motor vehicle has been licensed under the traffic laws of
the state, specifically 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes. This provision shall be
enforced without regard to whether the motor vehicle in question is susceptible
to licensing under the laws of the state. Provided, however, that the owner of
a motor vehicle shall not be prohibited under this section from driving said
vehicle on property which he owns, or in which he has any ownership or
leasehold interest.
   B.   Unlicensed Drivers: No person who is unlicensed to drive a motor
vehicle under the laws of the state, specifically 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes, shall drive any motor vehicle anywhere within the village limits.
Provided, however, that this section shall not apply to any driver who is
driving a motor vehicle upon property in which the driver holds an ownership or
leasehold interest. This section shall be enforced without regard to where the
offender resides.
   C.   Minors:
      1.   Warning: If a minor child is arrested for an offense committed under
subsection A or B of this section, the arresting officer shall return the minor
child to the custody of his or her parents or guardian. Upon returning the
minor child, the officer shall submit to the parent or guardian a written
warning, which warning shall read as follows: (Ord. 509, 11-19-1985)
WARNING: Your child, whose name is                       , has been arrested
for the offense of (driving an unlicensed vehicle in the Village of Manhattan/
driving a vehicle in the Village of Manhattan while unlicensed to drive). This
offense can subject the offender to a fine of up to $750.00 plus court costs.
This offense also gives the court the right to impose court supervision,
conditional discharge, probation, and various terms of work service upon the
offender. You are hereby notified that as the offender's parent or legal
guardian, you also may be subject to criminal prosecution if the minor child
again commits either of the above violations. The Village of Manhattan
Ordinances provide that where the parent or guardian allows a minor child to
operate a vehicle within the Village limits of Manhattan in violation of those
ordinances, that parent or legal guardian is also subject to a fine of up to
$750.00 plus court costs, and imposition by the court of court supervision,
conditional discharge, probation, including work release.
                                                            
   (Arresting Officer)
   Village of Manhattan Police Department
   Manhattan, Illinois
(Ord. 509, 11-19-1985; amd. Ord. 791, 8-5-2003)
      2.   Parental Liability: Any parent or guardian, having been first duly
warned in accordance with the provisions of this subsection C, shall be guilty
of the offense of allowing a minor child to drive an unlicensed motor vehicle
within the village of Manhattan, Illinois, if the minor child of said parent or
guardian commits a second or subsequent offense under this section. Any parent
or guardian, having first been duly warned under this subsection C, commits the
offense of allowing an unlicensed person to drive a motor vehicle within the
village, if his or her minor child commits a second or subsequent offense under
subsection B of this section. (Ord. 509, 11-19-1985)
10-1-3: SPEED LIMIT:
The maximum speed limit for motor traffic on all residential roads within the
village maintained by the village street department shall be twenty five (25)
miles per hour. (Ord. 536, 10-3-1989)
10-1-4: PARKING REGULATIONS:
See chapter 4 of this title for parking regulations. (Ord. 549, 5-21-1991)
10-1-5: VEHICLE EQUIPMENT AND CONDITION:
It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle which is not properly equipped with
good and efficient brakes, lights and signaling devices as required by state
law. (1928 Code §185)
10-1-6: PENALTY:
(Rep. by Ord. 1044, 1-19-2010)
10-1-7: NOISE; SPINNING WHEELS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle within the
village in such a manner as to cause or produce loud, excessive or unusual
noise by tire friction as a result of rapid turning, weaving or by the spinning
of wheels from a stopped, standing or slow moving position. (Ord. 508, 1985;
amd. Ord. 791, 8-5-2003)
10-1-8: DEPOSITING OF DIRT OR ROCK ON ROADWAY:
No vehicle shall be operated on any street in the village which causes, as a
result of the operation of such vehicle, the distribution, placing, leaving,
throwing, scattering or depositing of dirt, mud, stone, rock or other refuse
upon the roadway. (Ord. 859, 7-5-2005)
10-1-9: VEHICLE LOAD WEIGHTS; EXCEPTIONS; PERMITS:
   A.   Weight Regulations On Village Streets: The maximum weight limit
permitted on all nondesignated streets under the jurisdiction of the village
shall be eight (8) tons except for the following:
      Baker Road from Cedar Road to Eastern Avenue: Twelve (12) tons.
      Bruns/Gallagher Road from U.S. Route 52 to corporate limits: Twelve (12)
tons.
      Eastern Ave from E North Street to Smith Rd: Five (5) tons.
      Gougar Road from Manhattan Road to Sweedler Road: Twelve (12) tons.
      Pauling/Watkins Road from Kankakee Street to Cedar Road: Twelve (12)
tons.
      Smith Road from Cedar Road to U.S. Route 52: Twelve (12) tons.
      Sweedler Road from Front Street to Cherry Hill Road: Twelve (12) tons.
      All municipal roads shall be classified as nondesignated unless
signposted, state designated, or as provided for herein.
   B.   Vehicles With A Gross Weight In Excess Of Maximum Weight Limits On A
Nondesignated Municipal Road: It shall be unlawful to operate on any
nondesignated municipal road any motor vehicle with a gross weight, including
load, in excess of the maximum weight limits as set forth in subsection A of
this section, or in excess of special weight limits provided for by ordinance
and signposted, without having first obtained an overweight permit from the
police chief or his designee.
   This subsection shall not apply to any nondesignated municipal road which
has been designated by the village as a construction entrance, or to garbage
trucks, tow trucks, school buses, ambulances, firefighting vehicles, snowplows,
street maintenance vehicles, emergency vehicles, or vehicles making deliveries
on First Street from Park Road to U.S. Route 52 or Park Road from U.S. Route 52
to First Street, except that any of the aforesaid vehicles in excess of eighty
thousand (80,000) pounds must first obtain an overweight permit from the police
chief or his designee.
   This subsection shall not apply to trucks and other vehicles making
deliveries or off street parking on:
      Front Street from U.S. Route 52 to Sweedler/Elwood/Brown Road,
      Sweedler/Elwood/Brown Road from Front Street to corporate limits,
      except that the aforesaid vehicles in excess of eighty thousand (80,000)
pounds must first obtain an overweight permit from the police chief or his
designee.
   C.   Vehicles With A Gross Weight In Excess Of Eighty Thousand Pounds: It
shall be unlawful to operate a vehicle with a gross weight, including load, in
excess of eighty thousand (80,000) pounds, without first having obtained an
overweight permit from the police chief or his designee.
   D.   Application For Overweight Permit: Application for all overweight
permits shall be submitted in writing to the police chief or his designee on
the form provided and shall include, at a minimum:
      1.   The type of vehicle(s);
      2.   The weight to be transported;
      3.   The content to be transported;
      4.   The number of trips required;
      5.   The route to be taken by the vehicles;
      6.   The destination of the vehicles within the village; and
      7.   The name of the carrier, if different than the applicant.
   E.   Issuance Of Overweight Permit: Upon receipt of a completed application
and proof of payment of the fee, the police chief or his designee may issue an
overweight permit, subject to the following conditions:
      1.   In consideration of seasonal or other time limitations, the police
chief or his designee shall restrict the number or time of daily trips
authorized by each overweight permit, as is consistent with the public safety.
      2.   In establishing the routes to be traveled, the police chief or his
designee may establish the most direct and shortest route consistent with the
public safety, taking into consideration existing traffic, the character of the
road or roads, and the configuration of the terrain.
      3.   All overweight permits shall be nontransferable and shall be valid
only for the applicant or his agent or employee and the specific vehicle and
load listed on the application.
      4.   Every overweight permit shall be carried in the vehicle to which it
refers and shall be open to inspection by any police officer or agent of the
village.
      5.   No refunds of the overweight permit fee shall be made to the
applicant following the issuance of an overweight permit.
      6.   The applicant shall comply with all village, state, county, and
township ordinances, regulations and requirements.
      7.   Altering or falsifying a permit will revoke overweight permit
privileges for twelve (12) months.
      8.   No overweight permits will be issued for the following streets:
         McClure Avenue from Park Road to Gustafson Street.
         Railroad Street from East North Street to West Prairie Street.
         West Prairie Street from Railroad Street to U.S. Route 52.
   F.   Fee Schedule For Overweight Permit, Vehicle With A Gross Weight In
Excess Of Maximum Weight Limits On A Nondesignated Municipal Road: Overweight
permits for a motor vehicle with a gross weight, including load, in excess of
the maximum weight limits as set forth in subsection A of this section or in
excess of special weight limits provided for by ordinance and signposted, may
be applied for and may be granted in accordance with the following schedule:
      1.   Single trip permit: Thirty dollars ($30.00).
      2.   Round trip permit: Fifty dollars ($50.00).
      3.   Thirty (30) day permit: Seventy five dollars ($75.00).
      4.   One hundred twenty (120) day permit: One hundred fifty dollars
($150.00).
   G.   Fee Schedule For Overweight Permit, Vehicle With A Gross Weight In
Excess Of Eighty Thousand Pounds: Overweight permits for a motor vehicle with a
gross weight, including load, in excess of eighty thousand (80,000) pounds may
be applied for and may be granted according to the fee schedule as set forth in
section
10-1-1 of this chapter. (Ord. 1044, 1-19-2010; amd. Ord. 1421-23, 2-21-2023)
10-1-10: ENGINE BRAKING:
   A.   No person shall operate or cause to be operated at or upon any public
highway located within the village any compression/release engine brake on any
vehicle. For purposes of this section, a compression/release engine brake
(engine braking) is a mechanical exhaust device designed to aid in the braking
or deceleration of any vehicle by converting engine power to compressed air
which results in additional, excessive, loud or explosive noise from such
vehicle.
   B.   Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be
subject to a fine of not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) and not more
than as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. It shall be a defense that the driver used a compression/
release engine brake in an emergency to avoid a collision with a person or
another vehicle. (Ord. 1044, 1-19-2010)
10-1-11: VIOLATIONS, PENALTIES:
   A.   Violations, Penalties Generally: Unless as otherwise provided, any
person convicted of a violation of any section or provision of this chapter
shall be punished by a fine as established in section
1-4-1 of this code for any one offense. Each day such violation is committed or
permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be
punishable as such hereunder. (Ord. 1044, 1-19-2010; amd. Ord. 1061, 4-20-2010)
   B.   Penalty, Vehicle With A Gross Weight In Excess Of Maximum Weight Limits
On A Nondesignated Municipal Road: Every person, firm, or corporation who
violates this chapter operating a vehicle with a gross weight in excess of the
maximum weight limits as set forth in section
10-1-9 of this chapter, on a nondesignated municipal road, in addition to any
other fines, penalties, or restitution, shall be subject to a fine of not less
than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and not more than as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code; except that a vehicle with a gross weight in excess of
eighty thousand (80,000) pounds may be subject to the fines and penalties as
set forth in subsection C of this section.
Each occurrence shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as
such hereunder.
   C.   Penalty, Vehicle With A Gross Weight In Excess Of Prescribed Weight
Limits: Every person, firm, or corporation who violates this chapter operating
a vehicle with a gross weight in excess of prescribed weight limits, in
addition to any other fines, penalties, or restitution, shall be subject to the
fines and penalties as follows:
      1.   Weight: Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation of the
provisions of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-111 or 5/3-401(d), the owner
or driver of such vehicle shall be deemed guilty of such violation and either
the owner or the driver of such vehicle may be prosecuted for such violation.
Any person charged with a violation of any of these provisions who pleads not
guilty shall be present in court for the trial on the charge. Any person, firm
or corporation convicted of any violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
15-111, as enforced by the village, including, but not limited to, a maximum
axle or gross limit specified on a regulatory sign posted in accordance with
625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-111(g) or (h), in addition to any
surcharge, court costs, and fees, shall be fined according to the following
schedule:
Number Of Pounds Overweight  Fine

   Up to and including 2,0 $100.00
   2,001 through 2,500     270.00
   2,501 through 3,000     330.00
   3,001 through 3,500     520.00
   3,501 through 4,000     600.00
   4,001 through 4,500     850.00

   In addition, any person, firm or corporation convicted of four (4) or more
violations of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-111 within any twelve (12)
month period shall be fined an additional amount of five thousand dollars
($5,000.00) for the fourth and each subsequent conviction within the twelve
(12) month period. Provided, however, that with regard to a firm or
corporation, a fourth or subsequent conviction shall mean a fourth or
subsequent conviction attributable to any one employee driver.
   2.   Width, Height, Length Of Vehicles: Whenever any vehicle is operated in
violation of the provisions of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-102, 5/15-
103 or 5/15-107, the owner or driver of such vehicle shall be liable of such
violation and either may be prosecuted by the village prosecutor in the Will
County Circuit Court or through the village’s administrative adjudication
system pursuant to title 1 chapter 20 of this code, at the police officer’s
discretion, for such violation. Any person, firm or corporation convicted of
any violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-102, 5/15-103 or 5/15-107
shall be fined for the first or second conviction an amount equal to not less
than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), and
for the third and subsequent convictions by the same person, firm or
corporation within a period of one (1) year after the date of the first
offense, not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more than one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
   3.   Sentence Of Permit Moves: Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation
of the provisions of a permit issued under the provisions of 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/15-301 through 5/15-319, as enforced by the village, by
operating under a fraudulent permit or under a permit not specifically covering
the move, the owner or driver of such vehicle shall be deemed guilty of a
business offense and either the owner or the driver of such vehicle may be
prosecuted for such violation. When any person, firm or corporation is
convicted of such violation, the permit shall be null and void and such person,
firm or corporation shall be fined in an amount not less than ten cents ($0.10)
per pound for each pound the gross weight of the vehicle exceeds the gross
weight of such vehicles allowable under 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-
111. Penalties for violations of this section shall be in addition to any
penalties imposed for violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-301(j)
as enforced by the village.
   4.   Sentence Of Permit Moves Exceeding Axle Weights: Whenever any vehicle
is operated in violation of the provisions of a permit issued under the
provisions of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-301 through 5/15-319, as
enforced by the village, by operating with axle weights in excess of those
authorized in such permit, the owner or driver of such vehicle shall be deemed
guilty of a business offense and either the owner or the driver of such vehicle
may be prosecuted for such violation. Any person, firm or corporation convicted
of such violation shall be fined in an amount:
      Not less than two cents ($0.02) nor more than five cents ($0.05) per
pound for each pound of excess weight on such axle or tandem axle in excess of
the weight authorized in the permit when the excess is one thousand (1,000)
pounds or less;
      Not less than five cents ($0.05) nor more than ten cents ($0.10) per
pound for each pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds one thousand
(1,000) pounds and is two thousand (2,000) pounds or less;
      Not less than ten cents ($0.10) nor more than fifteen cents ($0.15) per
pound for each pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds two thousand
(2,000) pounds and is three thousand (3,000) pounds or less; and
      Not less than fifteen cents ($0.15) nor more than twenty cents ($0.20)
per pound for each pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds three
thousand (3,000) pounds.
      Penalties for violations of this section shall be in addition to any
penalties imposed for violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-301(j)
as enforced by the village.
   5.   Sentence Of Permit Moves Exceeding Gross Weight: Whenever any vehicle
is operated in violation of the provisions of a permit issued under the
provisions of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-301 through 5/15-319, as
enforced by the village, by operating with the gross weight in excess of that
authorized in such permit, the owner or driver of such vehicle shall be deemed
guilty of a business offense and either the owner or the driver of such vehicle
may be prosecuted for such violation. Any person, firm or corporation convicted
of such violation shall be fined in an amount:
      Not less than two cents ($0.02) nor more than five cents ($0.05) per
pound for each pound of excess weight in excess of the gross weight authorized
in the permit when the excess is one thousand (1,000) pounds or less;
      Not less than four cents ($0.04) nor more than seven cents ($0.07) per
pound for each pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds one thousand
(1,000) pounds and is two thousand (2,000) pounds or less;
      Not less than seven cents ($0.07) nor more than ten cents ($0.10) per
pound for each pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds two thousand
(2,000) pounds and is three thousand (3,000) pounds or less;
      Not less than ten cents ($0.10) nor more than fifteen cents ($0.15) per
pound for each pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds three thousand
(3,000) pounds and is four thousand (4,000) pounds or less;
      Not less than fifteen cents ($0.15) nor more than twenty cents ($0.20)
per pound for each pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds four thousand
(4,000) pounds and is five thousand (5,000) pounds or less; and
      Not less than seventeen cents ($0.17) nor more than twenty five cents
($0.25) per pound for each pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds five
thousand (5,000) pounds.
      Penalties for violations of this section shall be in addition to any
penalties imposed for violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-301(j)
as enforced by the village.
   6.   Registration, Second Division Vehicles: Whenever any vehicle is
operated in violation of the provisions of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-
401(d), in that a vehicle and load are operated in this state and the
appropriate fees and taxes have not been paid or the vehicle and load exceed
the registered gross weight for which the required fees and taxes have been
paid by two thousand one (2,001) pounds or more, the operator or owner shall be
fined according to the schedule as provided in subsection C1 of this section,
provided that for any unregistered vehicle or vehicle displaying expired
registration, no fine shall exceed the actual cost of what the appropriate
registration for that vehicle and load should have been as set forth below
regardless of the route traveled:

CHAPTER 2
VEHICLES PARKED UNLAWFULLY
SECTION:
10-2-1: Definitions
10-2-2: Time Limit For Leaving Vehicles On Property Within The Village
10-2-3: Authority To Inspect Vehicles
10-2-4: Authority To Impound Vehicles
10-2-5: Contents Of Notice
10-2-6: Record Searches
10-2-7: Reclaimed Vehicles; Disposal Of Unclaimed Vehicles
10-2-8: Penalty
10-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following words shall have the respective
meanings ascribed to them:
   ABANDONED VEHICLE: Any vehicle in a state of disrepair rendering the vehicle
incapable of being driven safely, or unlicensed or unregistered (except
vehicles for sale by new and used motor vehicle dealers and repair shops), or
left for such a time and under such circumstances as to reasonably appear to
have been abandoned or deserted. A vehicle is unlicensed when it does not have
a current set of valid license plates from the state in which the vehicle is
registered displayed on the vehicle. A vehicle is unregistered when it does not
have a current village vehicle sticker displayed on the windshield in
accordance with applicable law.
   ALLEY: A public way within a block generally giving access to the rear of
lots or buildings and not used for general traffic circulation.
   CHIEF OF POLICE: The chief of police or his authorized representative.
   HIGHWAY OR STREET: The entire width of public right of way of every way
publicly maintained and open to the use of the public for vehicular traffic.
   INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLE: Any motor vehicle from which, for a period of at
least seven (7) days, the engine, wheels or other parts have been removed, or
on which the engine, wheels or other parts have been altered, damaged or
otherwise so treated that the vehicle is incapable of being driven under its
own motor power. Inoperable motor vehicle shall not include a motor vehicle
which has been rendered temporarily incapable of being driven under its own
motor power in order to perform ordinary service or repair operations.
   OWNER: A person who holds legal title to a vehicle, a person who has
registered a vehicle in his name with the state of Illinois, or in the event a
vehicle is subject to an agreement for a conditional sale, lease, or mortgage
which vests an immediate right of possession in the conditional vendee, lessee
or mortgagor, then such conditional vendee, lessee, or mortgagor shall be
deemed the owner for the purpose of this chapter.
   URBAN DISTRICT: The territory contiguous to and including any street or
highway which is built up with structures devoted to business, industry or
dwelling houses situated at intervals of less than one hundred feet (100') for
a distance of a fourth of a mile or more. (Ord. 676, 7-7-1998, eff. retroactive
to 7-1-1998; amd. Ord. 868, 8-2-2005)
10-2-2: TIME LIMIT FOR LEAVING VEHICLES ON PROPERTY WITHIN THE VILLAGE:
   A.   Any vehicle, or any part thereof, which is on a highway and is
abandoned, burned, partially dismantled, unattended, or wrecked and creating a
traffic hazard because of its position in relation to the highway, or on a
highway and causing the impeding of traffic by its physical appearance, that
remains for any period of time, is unlawful.
   B.   Any vehicle, or any part thereof, which is on a highway and is
abandoned in an urban district that remains ten (10) hours or more, is
unlawful.
   C.   Any vehicle, or any part thereof, which is on a highway and is
abandoned or left unattended outside of an urban district that remains twenty
four (24) hours or more, is unlawful.
   D.   Any vehicle, or any part thereof, abandoned on public or private
property, other than a highway, in view of the general public, except on
property of the owner or bailee of such abandoned vehicle, that remains seven
(7) days or more, is unlawful.
   E.   Any vehicle, or any part thereof, abandoned, discarded, inoperable,
junked, partially dismantled, or wrecked on private property, and in view of
the general public, by any person in charge or control of said vehicle and
property, that remains thirty (30) days or more, is declared a nuisance and
unlawful. This chapter shall not apply to a vehicle in an enclosed building, a
vehicle on the premises of a business enterprise operated in a lawful place and
manner when necessary to the lawful operation of such business enterprise, or a
vehicle in an appropriate storage place or depository maintained in a lawful
place and manner by the village. (Ord. 868, 8-2-2005)
10-2-3: AUTHORITY TO INSPECT VEHICLES:
The chief of police is authorized to enter upon public or private property at
all reasonable hours for the purpose of inspecting vehicles reasonably believed
to be in violation of this chapter, and affix to such vehicle, in a conspicuous
location, in the form of an adhesive sticker, notice informing the owner of the
violation. It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent the chief of police
from entering public or private property for purposes of carrying out his
duties under this chapter or to interfere with him in the lawful performance of
his duties under the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 868, 8-2-2005)
10-2-4: AUTHORITY TO IMPOUND VEHICLES:
   A.   When a vehicle, or any part thereof, is on a highway and abandoned,
burned, inoperable, partially dismantled, unattended, or wrecked and creating a
traffic hazard because of its position in relation to the highway, or on a
highway and causing the impeding of traffic by its physical appearance, the
chief of police is hereby authorized to immediately remove or have removed said
vehicle, or any part thereof, in accordance with all applicable laws.
   B.   When a vehicle, or any part thereof, is abandoned on a highway in an
urban district that remains ten (10) hours or more, the chief of police is
hereby authorized to immediately remove or have removed said vehicle from the
highway in accordance with all applicable laws.
   C.   When a vehicle, or any part thereof, is abandoned or left unattended on
a highway, outside of an urban district, that remains twenty four (24) hours or
more, the chief of police is hereby authorized to immediately remove or have
removed said vehicle from the highway in accordance with all applicable laws.
   D.   When a vehicle, or any part thereof, is abandoned on private or public
property, other than a highway, in view of the general public, except on
property of the owner or bailee of such abandoned vehicle, that remains seven
(7) days or more, the chief of police is hereby authorized to remove or have
removed said vehicle, in accordance with all applicable laws; provided however
that no vehicle shall be removed and impounded until five (5) days after the
chief of police gives written notice of his intention to impound the vehicle,
if the vehicle has not been brought into compliance with the provisions of this
chapter at the end of such time. Such notice shall be given in the following
manner:
      1.   By leaving a copy of the notice with the owner of the vehicle
personally; or
      2.   Affixing a "police tow" notice on the vehicle; or
      3.   By sending a copy of the notice to the last known address of the
owner of the vehicle via certified or regular mail.
   E.   When a vehicle, or any part thereof, is abandoned, discarded,
inoperable, junked, partially dismantled, or wrecked on public or private
property, and in view of the general public, by any person in charge or control
of said vehicle and property, that remains thirty (30) days or more, the chief
of police is authorized to remove or have removed said vehicle, in accordance
with all applicable laws; provided however that no vehicle shall be removed and
impounded until after the chief of police issues a written notice of his
intention to impound the vehicle, and a notice to appear for a hearing in the
circuit court with competent jurisdiction. Such notice shall be given in the
following manner:
      1.   By leaving a copy of the notice with the owner of the vehicle
personally; or
      2.   By sending a copy of the notice to the last known address of the
owner of the vehicle by regular and certified mail; and
      3.   By sending a copy of the notice to the person in charge or control
of said property by regular and certified mail.
The chief of police may request an appropriate court order for the impoundment
of the vehicle at said hearing if the vehicle is not brought into compliance
with the provisions of this chapter. Upon obtaining an appropriate court order,
the chief of police is hereby authorized to remove or have removed said
vehicle, in accordance with all applicable laws. The enforcement of this
subsection is stayed when a hearing and/or decision is pending.
   F.   Such vehicle shall be impounded until lawfully claimed or disposed of
in accordance with 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/4-203 et seq., and the
provisions of this chapter.
   G.   The chief of police may tow or cause to be towed any vehicle
inoperable, abandoned, parked, or otherwise kept in violation of the provisions
of this chapter to a suitable storage area. (Ord. 868, 8-2-2005)
10-2-5: CONTENTS OF NOTICE:
The notice required to be given under this chapter shall contain the following
information:
   A.   The name of the owner of the vehicle, if available;
   B.   A description of the vehicle;
   C.   Location of the vehicle;
   D.   The nature of the violation;
   E.   The right to a pretow hearing (if applicable);
   F.   The owner of the vehicle shall be responsible for the fees and expenses
of towing, storage, impounding and enforcement. (Ord. 868, 8-2-2005)
10-2-6: RECORD SEARCHES:
When the identity of the owner of a vehicle is not known, the police department
will cause:
   A.   The vehicle registration records of the state to be searched by the
secretary of state for the purpose of obtaining the required ownership
information; and/or
   B.   The stolen motor vehicle files of the state police and the national
crime information center (NCIC) files to be searched by a directed
communication to the state police for stolen or wanted information on the
vehicle. (Ord. 868, 8-2-2005)
10-2-7: RECLAIMED VEHICLES; DISPOSAL OF UNCLAIMED VEHICLES:
   A.   Disposal of unclaimed vehicles shall be as set forth in the motor
vehicle code of the state, as amended.
   B.   Any time before a vehicle is sold or disposed of as provided in this
section, the owner of the vehicle may reclaim the vehicle by presenting to the
police department and the commercial towing service having custody of the
vehicle, proof of ownership or proof of right to possession of the vehicle. No
vehicle shall be released until all fees and expenses of towing, storage,
impounding and enforcement have been paid, and shall be in addition to the fine
provided for in this chapter for the violation of this chapter, unless
prohibited by law which requires the release of the vehicle without paying such
charges. Said fees and expenses may be collected by the village in an action at
law. (Ord. 868, 8-2-2005)
10-2-8: PENALTY:
Every person who is convicted of a violation of the provisions of this chapter
shall be punished by a fine as established in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 868, 8-2-2005; amd. Ord. 1061, 4-20-2010)
CHAPTER 3
VEHICLE LICENSES
(Rep. by Ord. 976, 9-18-2007, eff. 1-1-2008)
CHAPTER 4
PARKING REGULATIONS
SECTION:
10-4-1: Prohibited In Specified Places
10-4-2: One-Way Streets
10-4-3: Unattended Motor Vehicles
10-4-4: Powers Of Village Board To Restrict Parking
10-4-5: Presumption As To Identity Of Violator
10-4-6: Penalty
10-4-7: Commuter Parking Facility
10-4-8: On Street Parking Of Trailers
10-4-9: On Street Parking Of Trucks And Buses
10-4-1: PROHIBITED IN SPECIFIED PLACES:
   A.   Except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic, or in
compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or official traffic
control device, no person shall park a vehicle in any of the following places:
      1.   On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or
curb of a street.
      2.   On a sidewalk or a place where a sidewalk would normally be
constructed if there is no sidewalk.
      3.   Between the curb and the sidewalk or a place where a sidewalk would
normally be constructed if there is no sidewalk.
      4.   In front of a public or private driveway.
      5.   Within an intersection.
      6.   On a crosswalk.
      7.   Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty feet
(30') of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone,
unless a different length is indicated by signs or markings.
      8.   Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when such
parking would obstruct traffic.
      9.   Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway or within
a highway tunnel.
      10.   On any railroad tracks.
      11.   At any place where official signs prohibit parking.
      12.   In the area between roadways of a divided highway, including
crossovers.
      13.   In any area designated handicapped parking unless there is
displayed on such vehicle a registration plate, special decal, or other device
issued by any jurisdiction designating the vehicle as being operated by or for
a handicapped person.
      14.   Within fifteen feet (15') of a fire hydrant.
      15.   Within twenty feet (20') of a crosswalk at an intersection.
      16.   Within thirty feet (30') upon the approach to any flashing signal,
stop sign, yield sign or traffic control signal located at the side of the
roadway.
      17.   Within twenty feet (20') of the driveway entrance to any fire
station and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station
within seventy five feet (75') of such entrance (when properly signposted).
      18.   Within fifty feet (50') of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing.
      19.   At any place where official signs prohibit parking. (Ord. 549, 5-
21-1991)
      20.   On all streets after one inch (1") of snowfall or one quarter of an
inch (1/4") of ice buildup.
      21.   At Market Place Shopping Center, a thirty foot (30') fire lane is
hereby established for the property legally described in exhibit A, attached to
the ordinance codified herein and incorporated herein as if fully set forth,
beginning at the curb line in front of the shopping center building. Further,
that a minimum of seven (7) parking stalls shall be designated as handicapped
parking. Said handicapped parking stalls shall be properly marked by signs and
striping as required by state law.
         a.   The fine for parking in the designated fire lane shall be seventy
five dollars ($75.00) for the first offense, seventy five dollars ($75.00) for
the second offense and one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each subsequent
offense committed in the same calendar year. Further, the fine for parking in a
designated handicapped parking space without the proper license or placard
shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) per offense.
   B.   No person shall move a vehicle not lawfully under his control into any
such prohibited area or away from a curb such distance as is unlawful. (Ord.
549, 5-21-1991; amd. Ord. 682, 12-1-1998; Ord. 779, 1-7-2003; Ord. 1061, 4-20-
2010; Ord. 1362-21, 8-17-2021; Ord. 1425-23, 4-3-2023)
10-4-2: ONE-WAY STREETS:
   A.   Where parking is permitted, every vehicle standing, stopped or parked
upon a street or roadway shall be so stopped or parked with the right hand
wheels of such vehicle parallel with and within twelve inches (12") of the
right hand curb or edge of the roadway in the direction of the authorized
traffic movement.
   B.   Every vehicle stopped or parked upon a one-way roadway shall be so
stopped or parked parallel to the curb or edge of the roadway in the direction
of authorized traffic movement with its right hand wheels within twelve inches
(12") of the right hand curb or edge of the roadway or its left hand wheels
within twelve inches (12") of the left hand curb or edge of the roadway. (Ord.
549, 5-21-1991)
10-4-3: UNATTENDED MOTOR VEHICLES:
No person driving or in charge of a motor vehicle shall permit it to stand
unattended without first stopping the engine, locking the ignition, removing
the key from the ignition, effectively setting the brake thereon and, when
standing upon any perceptible grade, turning the front wheels to the curb or
side of the highway. (Ord. 549, 5-21-1991)
10-4-4: POWERS OF VILLAGE BOARD TO RESTRICT PARKING:
The village board may, from time to time, by resolution, designate certain
areas in and upon the streets of the village as being restricted against
parking, but where such areas are so designated by resolution, the areas shall
be appropriately marked by plain legible signs indicating such restriction.
(Ord. 549, 5-21-1991)
10-4-5: PRESUMPTION AS TO IDENTITY OF VIOLATOR:
Whenever any vehicle is parked in violation of any of the provisions of this
chapter, the registered owner of the vehicle shall be presumed to be the
violator. (Ord. 549, 5-21-1991)
10-4-6: PENALTY:
   A.   Any person convicted of a violation of any section or provision of this
chapter except for violation of parking in a handicap parking zone, shall be
punished by a fine as established in section
1-4-1 of this code for any one offense. Each day such violation is committed or
permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be
punishable as such hereunder. (Ord. 791, 8-5-2003; amd. Ord. 1061, 4-20-2010)
   B.   Any person convicted of a violation of parking in a handicap parking
zone shall be punished by a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for any one
offense. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall
constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder. (Ord.
992, 1-8-2008)
10-4-7: COMMUTER PARKING FACILITY:
   A.   Location: An area for commuter parking has been designated by the
village board and is located off of Sweedler Road west of the Metra commuter
line.
   B.   Fee: Fees for the use of the commuter parking facility have been
established by the village board to be paid on a daily basis of one dollar
($1.00) per day.
   C.   Parking Restrictions; Penalty For Violations; Payment Of Fee:
      1.   Parking in the following manner is prohibited in the commuter
parking lot:
         a.   There shall be no parking in nondesignated areas.
         b.   There shall be no parking except within the white lines of
designated parking spaces.
      2.   Individuals who violate any of the parking policies listed shall be
required to pay a fine in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each
violation and may be subject to having their vehicle towed if they are in
violation of subsection C1 of this section.
      3.   Individuals parking in the designated daily fee parking areas shall
place one dollar ($1.00) in the pay box coin slot corresponding to the number
of the stall in which they are parked. No money placed under windshield wipers
or in envelopes, or given to ticket agents or other Metra employees will be
accepted.
   D.   Insufficient Parking: The village is under no obligation to provide
parking for everyone, and as such is not accountable to those persons unable to
secure a legal parking space at any time.
   E.   Modification Of Regulations: The regulations set forth in this section
for the operation of the commuter parking facility are hereby established by
the direction of the president and board of trustees of the village of
Manhattan and are not subject to change, relief or modification by any party
other than by the president and board of trustees. (Ord. 881, 1-17-2006)
10-4-8: ON STREET PARKING OF TRAILERS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to park, store or
leave standing any trailer upon a public street or permit same under their
control to be parked, stored or left standing upon a public street unless it is
attached to a motor vehicle designed for and capable of towing it on a public
street. This section shall not prohibit the parking of construction or
maintenance trailers upon a public street during the time the actual
construction or maintenance activity is being conducted.
   B.   It shall be unlawful to park any trailer on any public street within
the village in such a manner as to interfere with the safe, normal use and flow
of traffic upon the street, whether or not attached to the tow vehicle.
   C.   "Trailer" shall mean, but is not limited to, any vehicle designed or
utilized for the transportation of a boat, automobile, snowmobile, livestock,
cargo or similar items or as living quarters for recreation, camping or travel
use as in the case of a travel, tent, camp pop up or fifth wheel trailer, which
does not have motive power of its own, but is designed to be drawn by a
vehicle. (Ord. 992, 1-8-2008)
10-4-9: ON STREET PARKING OF TRUCKS AND BUSES:
It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to park, store or leave
standing within any residential district upon a public street any truck tractor
of any size, apportioned power unit, semitrailer, stinger steered semitrailer,
road tractor, pole trailer, converter dolly, apportioned trailer, apportioned
semitrailer, type B or greater bus, whether privately owned or a school bus,
implement of husbandry or any vehicle requiring an Illinois registration plate
suffix of "H" or greater, including foreign registered vehicles, which would
require such registration, if registered in Illinois, any vehicle required to
have mileage plates of "MG" suffix or greater, farm plates of "VG" or greater,
or tow trucks capable of towing any vehicle which is prohibited under this
section. (Ord. 1051, 3-2-2010)
CHAPTER 5
SNOWMOBILES AND OTHER OFF ROAD VEHICLES
SECTION:
10-5-1: Operation; Speed Limit
10-5-2: Designated Routes
10-5-3: Definitions
10-5-4: State Statute
10-5-5: Local Regulations
10-5-6: Penalty
10-5-1: OPERATION; SPEED LIMIT:
   A.   No one shall operate a snowmobile or ATV in the corporate limits of the
village of Manhattan on any other streets or other public rights of way within
the village other than the routes designated in section
10-5-2 of this chapter, except that operators may use village streets or other
public rights of way between where the snowmobile, ATV or off highway
motorcycle is stored and a designated route. However, operators shall use the
most direct path to a designated route. (Ord. 767, 7-16-2002)
   B.   Operators shall travel along the shoulder of a road or other right of
way in the same direction as other vehicular traffic and shall comply with all
regulatory signage on said roadway. The maximum speed limit for snowmobiles and
ATVs shall be fifteen (15) miles per hour.
   C.   Operation of a snowmobile or ATV on private property is prohibited
without the permission of the owner.
   D.   Operators shall not operate a snowmobile or ATV in such a manner as to
damage public or private property. (Ord. 685, 1-5-1999)
10-5-2: DESIGNATED ROUTES:
The following streets and roads within the corporate limits of the village are
hereby designated as snowmobile and ATV routes within the village:
   East North Street from the eastern corporate limits to Eastern Avenue.
   Eastern Avenue from State Street to Baker Road.
   Elwood Road from Front Street to the western corporate limits.
   Front Street from State Street to Elwood Road.
   Park Street from State Street to McClure Avenue.
   Prairie Street from Eastern Avenue to the railroad tracks.
   Prairie Street from Railroad Street to West North Street.
   Railroad Street from East North Street to Prairie Street.
   State Street from Eastern Avenue to the southern corporate limits.
   Wabash Street from East North Street to State Street.
   West North Street from Prairie Street to the northern corporate limits.
   Western Avenue from West North Street to the western corporate limits. (Ord.
685, 1-5-1999)
10-5-3: DEFINITIONS:
   ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLE: Any motorized off highway device designed to travel
primarily off highway that is fifty inches (50") or less in width, having a
manufacturer's dry weight of one thousand (1,000) pounds or less, traveling on
three (3) or more low pressure tires, designed with a seat or saddle for
operator use, and handlebars or steering wheel for steering control. This
excludes vehicles commonly known as a go-kart.
   OFF HIGHWAY MOTORCYCLE: Any motorized device designed to travel primarily
off highway on two (2) wheels, having a seat or saddle for the use of the
operator, upon or by which any person, persons or property may be transported
or drawn, commonly referred to as a dirt bike.
   SNOWMOBILE: A self-propelled device designed for travel on snow or ice or
natural terrain steered by skis or runners, and supported in part by skis,
belts or cleats. (Ord. 767, 7-16-2002)
10-5-4: STATE STATUTE:
The provisions of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-1426 through and
including 5/11-1427.4 are hereby incorporated herein as if fully set forth.
(Ord. 767, 7-16-2002)
10-5-5: LOCAL REGULATIONS:
   A.   All-Terrain Vehicles: In addition to the state statutes incorporated
herein by section
10-5-4 of this chapter, no person shall operate an all-terrain vehicle in the
corporate limits of the village of Manhattan except in accordance with the
following regulations:
      1.   Operators shall have a valid driver's license in good standing;
      2.   Operators shall be a minimum of sixteen (16) years of age;
      3.   Operators and all passengers shall wear a helmet at all times the
ATV or off highway motorcycle is in motion;
      4.   No ATV shall be operated unless the headlight(s) and rear taillight
(s) are on and in good working order.
   B.   Off Highway Motorcycles And Go-Karts Prohibited: The operation of off
highway motorcycles and go-karts is hereby prohibited on all public property in
the corporate limits of the village, including, but not limited to, streets,
sidewalks, parkways, parks, detention ponds, schools and other government and
public facilities. (Ord. 767, 7-16-2002)
10-5-6: PENALTY:
Any person convicted of a violation of any section or provision of this chapter
shall be punished by a fine as established in section
1-4-1 of this code for any one offense. (Ord. 791, 8-5-2003; amd. Ord. 1061, 4-
20-2010)
CHAPTER 6
VEHICLE SEIZURE AND IMPOUNDMENT
SECTION:
10-6-1: Nuisance Declared
10-6-2: Seizure And Impoundment
10-6-3: Administrative Fee
10-6-4: Vehicle Possession
10-6-5: Preliminary Hearing
10-6-6: Administrative Hearing
10-6-7: Failure To Pay
10-6-8: Right To Appeal
10-6-1: NUISANCE DECLARED:
   A.   Any motor vehicle used in connection with the following shall be
declared a public nuisance and subject to seizure and impoundment under this
chapter:
      1.   A violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statues 5/6-101, operating a
motor vehicle with an expired license, permit, or a restricted driving permit
if the period of expiration is greater than one year, or operating a motor
vehicle without ever having been issued a driver’s license or permit;
      2.   A violation of section
9-3-6 , "Fireworks", or section
9-6-2 , possession (of cannabis or drug paraphernalia), of this code;
      3.   A violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-303, driving while
driver's license, permit or privilege to operate a motor vehicle is suspended
or revoked, of the vehicle code, except a person whose driver's license, permit
or privilege to operate a motor vehicle is suspended only for a violation of
625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/13 et seq., the emissions inspection law;
      4.   A violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-204, fleeing or
attempting to elude a peace officer, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-501,
driving under the influence of alcohol, other drug or drugs, intoxicating
compound or compounds or any combination thereof, 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-503, reckless driving or aggravated reckless driving, 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-506, street racing or aggravated street racing,
or 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-601.5, driving forty (40) miles an hour
or more in excess of applicable limit, of the vehicle code;
      5.   A person who is found to be in control of a motor vehicle against
whom a warrant has been issued by a circuit court;
      6.   A violation of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-6, indecent
solicitation of a child, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/12-2, aggravated
assault, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/12-4, aggravated battery, 720
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/12-4.2, aggravated battery with a firearm, 720
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/12-4.3, aggravated battery of a child, 720
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/12-4.6, aggravated battery of a senior citizen,
720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/16A-3, retail theft, when the value of the
merchandise exceeds three hundred dollars ($300.00), 720 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/18-1, robbery, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/18-2, armed robbery,
720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/19-1, burglary, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/19-3, residential burglary, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/20-1, arson, 720
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/20-1.1, aggravated arson, 720 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/20-2, possession of explosives or explosive or incendiary devices,
720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-1, criminal damage to property, or 720
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/25-1, mob action, of the Illinois criminal code;
      7.   A violation of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 570/401, manufacture
or delivery unauthorized, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 570/401.1, controlled
substance trafficking, or 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 570/402, possession
unauthorized, of the controlled substances act;
      8.   A violation of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/4, possession of
cannabis, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/5, manufacture or delivery of
cannabis, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/5.1, cannabis trafficking, 720
Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/5.2, delivery of cannabis on school grounds, or
720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/8, unauthorized production or possession of
Cannabis sativa plant, of the cannabis control act; or
      9.   A violation of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 600/3.5, possession of
drug paraphernalia, of the drug paraphernalia control act.
   B.   Any motor vehicle which is used in connection with the following shall
be declared a public nuisance and subject to seizure and impoundment under this
chapter: a violation of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-1, unlawful use of
weapon, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-3.1, unlawful possession of
firearms and firearm ammunition, or 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-3.3,
unlawful sale or delivery of firearms on the premises of any school. This
subsection shall not apply when the exemptions are satisfied as set forth in
720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-2. (Ord. 1007, 11-4-2008; amd. Ord. 1319-
20, 2-4-2020; Ord. 1457-24, 5-7-2024)
10-6-2: SEIZURE AND IMPOUNDMENT:
Whenever a police officer has probable cause to believe that a motor vehicle is
subject to seizure and impoundment pursuant to this chapter, the police officer
shall provide for the towing of the motor vehicle according to police
department procedures. When the motor vehicle is towed, the police officer
shall notify the person who is found to be in control of the motor vehicle at
the time of the alleged violation, if there is such a person, of the fact of
the seizure and of the motor vehicle owner's right to request a preliminary
hearing. Said motor vehicle shall be impounded pending the completion of the
hearings provided for in this chapter, unless the owner of the motor vehicle
posts with the village a cash bond as set forth in section
10-6-3 of this chapter. (Ord. 1007, 11-4-2008)
10-6-3: ADMINISTRATIVE FEE:
The owner of record of such motor vehicle subject to seizure and impoundment
shall be liable to the village for an administrative fee of five hundred
dollars ($500.00) in addition to any towing and storage charges. This chapter
is in addition to and shall not replace or otherwise abrogate any existing
state or federal laws or any ordinance that relates to the seizure and/or
impoundment of motor vehicles, and any fee in this chapter shall be in addition
to any and all penalties that may be assessed or imposed by a court for any
criminal charges. This chapter shall not apply: (Ord. 1007, 11-4-2008; amd.
Ord. 1062, 4-20-2010)
   A.   If the motor vehicle used in the violation was stolen at that time and
the theft was reported to the appropriate police authorities within twenty four
(24) hours after the theft was discovered;
   B.   If the motor vehicle is operating as a common carrier and the violation
occurs without the knowledge of the person in control of the motor vehicle; or
   C.   If the motor vehicle is subject to successful forfeiture proceedings
under 725 Illinois Compiled Statutes 150/1 et seq., the drug asset forfeiture
procedure act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/36-1 et seq., the seizure and
forfeiture of vessels, vehicles and aircraft act, or state or federal
forfeiture laws.
For purposes of this chapter, the "owner of record" or "owner" of a motor
vehicle is the record titleholder as registered with the secretary of state,
state of Illinois, or similar entity in a different state. (Ord. 1007, 11-4-
2008)
10-6-4: VEHICLE POSSESSION:
   A.   Except as provided otherwise in this chapter, a motor vehicle shall
continue to be impounded until:
      1.   The administrative fee, plus any applicable towing and storage
charges, are paid, in which case possession of the motor vehicle shall be given
to the person who is legally entitled to possess the motor vehicle;
      2.   A finding that a violation of this chapter did not occur after a
preliminary hearing or an administrative hearing; or
      3.   The motor vehicle is sold or otherwise disposed of to satisfy a
judgment to enforce a lien as provided by law.
   B.   Except as otherwise specifically provided by law, no owner, lienholder
or other person shall be legally entitled to take possession of a motor vehicle
impounded under this chapter until the civil fees applicable under this chapter
have been paid. (Ord. 1007, 11-4-2008)
10-6-5: PRELIMINARY HEARING:
If the owner of a motor vehicle seized pursuant to this chapter requests a
preliminary hearing, said owner must make a request for said preliminary
hearing within forty eight (48) hours of the seizure and impoundment. Said
request shall be made in person and in writing at the police department
administrative offices, Monday through Friday, excluding holidays, nine o'clock
(9:00) A.M. through five o'clock (5:00) P.M. using the tow hearing request
form. If the request for a preliminary hearing is timely filed, the chief of
police or his designee shall conduct such preliminary hearing within twenty
four (24) hours after the request, or by a date mutually agreeable to the
parties, Monday through Friday, excluding holidays, nine o'clock (9:00) A.M.
through five o'clock (5:00) P.M. All interested persons shall be given a
reasonable opportunity to be heard at the preliminary hearing. The formal rules
of evidence will not apply and hearsay evidence shall be admissible. If, after
the preliminary hearing, the chief of police or his designee determines there
is probable cause to believe that the motor vehicle is subject to seizure and
impoundment pursuant to this chapter, the chief of police or his designee shall
order the continued impoundment of the motor vehicle, as provided in this
chapter, unless the owner of the motor vehicle posts with the village a cash
bond as set forth in section
10-6-3 of this chapter. However, if the chief of police or his designee finds
that no such violation occurred, the chief of police or his designee shall
order the return of the motor vehicle or cash bond, but the owner shall be
responsible for any towing and storage charges. (Ord. 1007, 11-4-2008)
10-6-6: ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING:
The hearing officer shall hold an administrative hearing if the owner, within
thirty (30) days of the motor vehicle seizure and impoundment, affirmatively
requests an administrative hearing in writing. Said request shall be made in
person and in writing at the Manhattan village hall, Monday through Friday,
excluding holidays, nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. through four thirty o'clock (4:30)
P.M. using the administrative hearing request form. The hearing shall be
conducted and held, unless the motor vehicle was subject to successful
forfeiture proceedings pursuant to applicable state or federal forfeiture laws,
no later than forty six (46) days after the motor vehicle was seized, unless
continued by the owner or by order of the hearing officer; or unless the motor
vehicle was subject to unsuccessful forfeiture proceedings, in which case the
hearing shall be conducted and held, unless continued by the owner or by order
of the hearing officer, no later than forty six (46) days after the conclusion
of the forfeiture proceedings. All interested persons shall be given a
reasonable opportunity to be heard at the hearing. At any time prior to the
hearing date, the hearing officer may, at the request of either party, direct
witnesses to appear and give testimony at the hearing. The formal rules of
evidence will not apply at the hearing and hearsay evidence shall be
admissible. If, after the hearing, the hearing officer determines by a
preponderance of evidence that the motor vehicle, operated with the permission,
express or implied, of the owner, was used in the commission of any of the
violations set forth in this chapter, and that none of the exceptions apply,
the hearing officer shall enter an order finding the owner of record of the
motor vehicle civilly liable to the village for an administrative fee in the
amount as set forth in section
10-6-3 of this chapter, which shall constitute a debt due and owing to the
village. If the owner of record fails to appear at the hearing, the hearing
officer shall enter a default order finding the owner of record of the motor
vehicle civilly liable to the village for an administrative fee in the amount
as set forth in section
10-6-3 of this chapter, which shall constitute a debt due and owing to the
village, and a copy of which default order shall be sent to the registered
owner via certified mail, return receipt requested. If a cash bond has been
posted, the bond shall be applied. If a motor vehicle has been impounded when
such administrative fee is imposed, the village may seek to obtain a judgment
on the debt and enforce such judgment against the motor vehicle as provided by
law. However, if the hearing officer finds that no such violation occurred, the
hearing officer shall order the return of the motor vehicle or cash bond, but
the owner shall be responsible for any towing and storage charges. (Ord. 1007,
11-4-2008)
10-6-7: FAILURE TO PAY:
If the administrative fee and towing and storage charges are not paid:
   A.   After the time to request an administrative hearing has expired for an
owner of record who did not request an administrative hearing, or
   B.   Within thirty (30) days after entry of an administrative fee against an
owner of record who requested a hearing and the owner did not file a petition
for judicial review, or
   C.   Within thirty (30) days after an action seeking judicial review has
been resolved in favor of the village,
the village shall be authorized to dispose of said vehicle (including contents
and license plates) in the manner provided by law for the disposition of
unclaimed motor vehicles. (Ord. 1007, 11-4-2008)
10-6-8: RIGHT TO APPEAL:
Upon a finding after an administrative hearing that the motor vehicle was used
in the commission of any of the violations set forth in this chapter and that
the owner of record of the motor vehicle is civilly liable to the village for
an administrative fee, the owner has a right to petition for judicial review
within thirty (30) days of the finding. If a petition for judicial review is
filed, a copy must be provided to the village no later than seventy two (72)
hours after filing said petition. (Ord. 1007, 11-4-2008)
CHAPTER 7
GOLF CARTS AND RECREATIONAL OFF-HIGHWAY VEHICLES
SECTION:
10-7-1: Definitions
10-7-2: Requirements
10-7-3: Annual Registration
10-7-4: Registration Fee
10-7-5: Penalty
10-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
 
COUNTY       Any road under the jurisdiction of Will County highway department.
ROADS:
             A vehicle specifically designed and intended for the purposes of transporting
             one or more persons and their golf clubs or maintenance equipment while engaged
GOLF CART:   in the playing of golf, supervising the playing of golf or maintaining the
             condition of the grounds on a public or private golf course and having a maximum
             speed of twenty (20) miles per hour.
             Any motorized off-highway device designed to travel primarily off-highway, 64
RECREATIONAL inches or less in width, having a manufacturer’s dry weight of 2,000 pounds or
OFF-HIGHWAY  less for gas-powered engines or 3,000 pounds or less for electric-powered
VEHICLE:     engines, traveling on 4 or more non-highway tires, designed with a non-straddle
             seat and a steering wheel for steering control, except equipment such as
             lawnmowers.
STATE ROADS: Any road under the jurisdiction of the Illinois department of transportation.
             State roads include U.S. Route 52 and North Street.
TOWNSHIP     Any road under the jurisdiction of Manhattan Township road district.
ROADS:
             Any of the streets within the boundaries of the village of Manhattan except for
VILLAGE      state roads and county roads, but including township roads within the village

10-7-2: REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Golf carts and recreational off-highway vehicles may be operated on
village streets subject to the following:
      1.   The driver is subject to the mandatory vehicle liability insurance
requirements of Illinois and must carry proof of such insurance, specifically
insuring the golf cart or recreational off-highway vehicle.
      2.   The driver must have a valid driver’s license issued by the Illinois
secretary of state or by a foreign jurisdiction.
      3.   When operated on village, county, township or state streets, a golf
cart or recreational off-highway vehicle shall have its headlights and
taillamps illuminated at all times, including, but not limited to, times when
rain, snow, fog or other atmospheric conditions require the use of windshield
wipers and at any other time when, due to insufficient light or unfavorable
atmospheric conditions, persons and vehicles on the street, road or highway are
not clearly discernible at a distance of one thousand feet (1,000').
      4.   The golf cart or recreational off-highway vehicle shall be equipped
with brakes, a steering wheel apparatus, tires, a rearview mirror, red
reflective warning devices on the front and rear, an approved slow moving
vehicle emblem on the rear of the golf cart or recreational off-highway
vehicle, a headlight that emits a white light visible from a distance of five
hundred feet (500') to the front, a taillamp that emits a red light visible
from at least one hundred feet (100') from the rear, brake lights, turn
signals, side marker lights, and seatbelts or safety seats if transporting
children under the age of eight (8).
      5.   The capacity (the number of occupants) of the golf cart or
recreational off-highway vehicle shall not exceed the manufacture’s
specifications. Drivers are required to comply with child passenger safety
laws. The transportation of a child under the age of eight (8) years old is
prohibited, unless the child is accompanied by an adult (21 or older).
Appropriate seat belts and safety seats are required to transport children as
required under the Illinois Compiled Statutes and village ordinances.
      6.   The golf cart or recreational off-highway vehicle driver shall obey
all traffic laws of the state of Illinois and the village of Manhattan with
regard to the movement, operation, parking, and storage of vehicles on the
streets, roadways and private property.
      7.   Golf carts or recreational off-highway vehicles may only be operated
on streets with posted speed limits of thirty five (35) miles per hour or less.
This subsection A7 does hereby prohibit a golf cart or recreational off-highway
vehicle from crossing a village street at an intersection where the village
street has a posted speed limit of more than thirty five (35) miles per hour,
unless as set forth in subsection A9 of this section.
      8.   Golf carts or recreational off-highway vehicles may be operated only
on Manhattan-Monee Road between and including the intersections of Railroad
Street and Wabash Street and Route 52 between and including the intersections
of Front Street and Wabash Street (attached to the ordinance codified herein
and incorporated herein as exhibit A is a map of streets on which golf carts
may be operated).
      9.   Drivers of a golf cart or recreational off-highway vehicle may make
a direct crossing upon or across a street or road if the street or road has a
speed limit of thirty five (35) miles per hour or higher only if the crossing
is made at an intersection controlled by a traffic signal or a four-way stop
sign.
      10.   The driver of the golf cart or recreational off-highway vehicle
shall not exceed any posted speed limit.
      11.   A driver or person in actual physical control of the golf cart or
recreational off-highway vehicle on a street or road while under the influence
of alcohol or drugs is subject to section 11-500 through 11-502 of the Illinois
vehicle code statutes, and applicable village of Manhattan ordinances.
      12.   Golf carts or recreational off-highway vehicles may not be operated
on sidewalks, bike paths, ATV trails, snowmobile trails or other public
property not accessible to or authorized for vehicular traffic.
      13.   No “nonhighway” vehicle as defined by 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-1426.1 is permitted on village streets, roads or highways except
golf carts or recreational off-highway vehicles.
      14.   All crossings of streets, roads and highways must be direct
crossings made at an intersection.
      15.   All golf carts or recreational off-highway vehicles in order to be
operated as provided herein must register annually with the village of
Manhattan and have a current registration sticker purchased from the village of
Manhattan.
      16.   The requirements of this chapter apply to golf carts or
recreational off-highway vehicles within the village of Manhattan that are
intended to be used on village streets as provided herein. (Ord. 1404-22, 7-19-
2022; amd. Ord. 1443-23, 12-5-2023)
10-7-3: ANNUAL REGISTRATION:
   A.   All golf carts or recreational off-highway vehicles, in order to be
driven on village streets, must be registered annually with the village of
Manhattan. All registrations shall be issued by the police department unless
otherwise specifically provided, and shall be for the term of one year,
expiring on May 31 of each year. The registration sticker shall be displayed on
the rear of the vehicle in the center of the reflective slow moving vehicle
emblem.
   B.   Golf carts or recreational off-highway vehicles possessing valid
registration from another community and participating in an organized event or
parade within the village of Manhattan are exempt from registration for the day
of the event only. (Ord. 1404-22, 7-19-2022; amd. Ord. 1443-23, 12-5-2023)
10-7-4: REGISTRATION FEE:
   A.   The annual registration fee for a golf cart or recreational off-highway
vehicle in the village shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). (Ord. 1404-22, 7-
19-2022; amd. Ord. 1443-23, 12-5-2023)
10-7-5: PENALTY:
   A.   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall upon
conviction be subject to a fine as established in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 1404-22, 7-19-2022; amd. Ord. 1443-23, 12-5-2023)
